description:
I came to City Hall for an evening wedding and the place is beautiful, definitely one of the best places to have a wedding because of all the great background decor.

It was on the weekend so I had a chance to really tour the space and get a feel for all the design and architecture.
author: Tracey M.

description:
This is a beautiful building in a dangerous area. Go figure. City buildings are generally downtown, & downtown in most world class cities can be dangerous.
Fun bit of trivia: the dome on SF City Hall is ranked 5th tallest on the planet!
Don't miss the art in the basement level!
author: Eugenia T.

description:
One of the most beautiful buildings in San Francisco. Thinking of an elopement or a destination wedding. San Francisco City Hall Weddings are the most beautiful. You get to focus on eachother , take gorgeous photos and afterwards have a wonderful meal at a plethora of eateries here in the city. 
And if you are ever thinking of having your Hair and Makeup done for your Wedding at City Hall. Please give me a call. I would love to style you ;) haha. no- seriously!
Cheers to the beautiful San Francisco City Hall!!!!

www.sfcityhallweddings.love

~Lia Negrete
Hair and Makeup Artist
San Francisco,Ca.
author: Lia N.

description: I was trying to figure out how I was getting back to my hotel from a local ice cream shop, and walked by City Hall. I can only speak of just viewing City Hall from the outside at night. The building is very picturesque late night, so I took a few pictures with my trusty Pixel XL phone. I noticed across the street, I could take a wider shot of the building and realized that there was an army of figures. These funny statues added a little character to my photos. The building is well lit at night, a great Instagram photo opportunity!
author: Antonio L.

description:
The city may be filled with crazy junkies passed out on thre streets in there own vomit and excrement.

The streets may be falling apart with potholes the size of a VW bug.

....But City Hall looks like a million bucks ( well more like 293 million bucks but heck who's counting) http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1999-01-03/news/9901030185_1_city-hall-dome-renovation-deadly-earthquake

Nevertheless it is a beautiful building and the employees are pretty great. I needed some recorded documents and the lady that helped me was fantastic: Friendly. Helpful, and patient ( gee gosh now I feel much better about paying my Gross Sales recipts tax .....kinda)
author: David G.

description: Came to get certified data. They are closed for some holiday that the rest of us don't get. Ugh!!
author: Dee Was Here Z.

description:
Impressive building even you can only admire the outside. Entering requires security check. I saw a married couple and outside there was a music festival in the front.
But worth to see how impressive this is, look up the background on this building as it was inspired by an Italian treasure.
author: Apple S.

description:
Great place for weddings and there were weddings on every floor when we were there. Our niece's wedding was on the 4th floor. Its $1000 for an hour.

Parking is below but was closed today so we had to do a parking garage a couple of blocks away.

They do security screening but it's pretty basic.
author: Chris A.

description: Seeing pictures of city hall, I knew this was where I wanted to get married. Parking was easy. It wasn't as crowded as I thought it would be. We were the last wedding before their lunch break. The process was really easy. We got married at the top of the grand stair case. We had more than 6 people but the officiant didn't mind. There were lots of areas for pictures and the building just lends itself for photo ops.
author: Manjit Z.

description:
Not on the top of your must-see list in SF, but if you have time why not stop by

The City Hall area is a government district with City Hall, government buildings, court offices, a library, the Asian Art Museum (this you have to pay for) and more. It's so nice that there's marriages happening the in hallways of City Hall. I came on a day when there was even a farmers' market going on outside. Only problem is there's a lot of homeless people everywhere, more than usual. SF needs to fix this problem.
author: Vincent H.

description:
I recently got married here! The ceremony is definitely memorable and budget-friendly. If you want a small, non-religious, formal, but not traditionally lavishing ceremony, this is the best place!

You need to spend around an hour for the marriage ceremony process. Arrive at least 10 min before the reserved time. After the security check, find the county clerk office. You need to firstly have paperwork examined by an official. She/he will check your marriage license and IDs. 

Then, you will wait approximately 30 min to meet the commissioner with your witness(es) in his/her office. (They will give you a number so you can comfortably seated). The commissioner will ask your witness to sign the license. Only the couple and the witness(es) are allowed in the office.

Then, you can choose a private place or the second floor above the main hall stair to hold the ceremony. The same commissioner will hold the ceremony for you. We (and I see many couples) chose the main hall. The great place, and the seriousness but friendliness of the commissioner, is impressive. (The bride before us even cried during the commisioner's speech.) Although they claim you can have 6 people to attend the ceremony, actually they don't count. As long as you do not bring an army, there are plenty space. The ceremony is around 10 minutes. But you may need to wait for the commissioner to hold ceremony for other couples. 

My suggestion is to reserve an early time (10am maybe) so there are not many tourists in the main hall. (Or you actually like the tourists because they will applause for you at the end of the ceremony?). My ceremony was at 12:30 and it was a little bit noisy at background.
author: Y C.

description:
Dear City Hall, 

The one moment that sticks out most is being married on your marble steps. We were a young couple in love that just wanted to get married. No judgements, no bling, no social stereotypes. What better place than on the steps of the historic, over a century old, City Hall. A Beaux-Arts monument to the city of San Francisco, a time of high-minded American Renaissance. Your dome is 42-feet taller than that of the United States Capitol! 

You are a beacon of equality, fairness, and just plain decency. And although time has passed on by, we grew apart, & went our separate ways, I will always remember that moment of "I do" in San Francisco, California. 

Thank you for the memories, City Hall. 

Always, Eric
author: Eric R.

description:
Everyone loves this building. It was very well designed with no expenses spared. Beautiful marble details every where and extremely well crafted. Completed in 1913 the dome at 307 feet in height, is 42 feet taller than the dome of the nation's capitol.

The Loma Prieta earthquake of October 17, 1989 damaged it severely. The earth retrofit was completed in 1999 and it included a base isolation system to protect the building from future large earthquakes.

A popular place for wedding photography, right after tying the knot at the wedding registry. There is no charge for entry so come and enjoy this classical architecture.
author: Keo N.

description:
In the heart of San Francisco, California, this well recognized  "Beaux-Arts" architectural building serves the neighbors in a perfect harmony. The San Francisco's City Hall it is which makes this place the best coming attractions for any special occasions of every season no matter what the consequences for both residents and tourists alike.

I did likely visited to the SF City Hall a long time ago back in the early 2000s, and it was a magical experience! Inside, they have tons of magnificent views and historic wonders from the glorious, restored interior structures, beautiful aspects of the Rotunda, nice natural light displays and awe-inspired New York's Grand Central like atmosphere. It's officially welcomed to the public at anytime although it's defientitly the most popular of all is wedding photographs! Furthermore, it's also the home of the San Francisco mayor at this city hall too!

Of course, the San Francisco's City Hall has tons of historic artifacts and special occasions moments from the beginning to the current. The City Hall did survived two earthquakes (both in 1906 and 1989) despite the minor destructive damages and renovations. 20th Century celebrities like Marilyn Monroe did married there back in the mid 1950s. Finally, in this modern generations of today, the city hall are always doing mostly seasonal and top priority events like St Patrick's Day Parade and Festival (every March), 3X San Francisco Giants' World Series Championships Celebration, and the Christmas tree lightning ceremony.

Parking at the SF City Hall can be challenging to park. You can park the the nearby surface metered street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. You can also alternatively ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, the San Francisco City Hall is the finest and the most recognizable monument that I've ever experienced and visited for many years! Perfect for special occasions and tourists attractions all year long! A well visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
This review is for Room 168, City Clerk. I had questions regarding a notice in the mail for supposed 'delinquent taxes'. The clerk was warm , friendly and knowledgeable. He walked me through how to address this amount online and turns out it was regarding a Business License renewal. Turns out I owe nothing as I don't wish to renew it, but just needed to step through a process online.  

I waited 2 minutes to be served -- no queue! In and out.
author: Tilly D.

description: I went to San Francisco City Hall to participate my friend's wedding as a witness. It's a beautiful building. I understand why people love to go there. They're right
author: Yumiko H.

description: I can't believe I haven't reviewed this City Hall yet! My husband and I got married here on our 3 year anniversary! After he proposed, we started planning for an actual big wedding. Looking at the costs of everything, we both didn't want to spend that kind of money on one night with a dress and tux that we'll never wear again. So we decided to come here since we already knew how BEAUTIFUL this place really is! Some people think, city hall. Must be cramped, hot, ugly old building. This is SO far from it. We spent a lot of money on my photographer friend, because I knew the photos from our special day is what I will cherish the most. I could go on and on about the beauty of this place, but I'll just post some pictures of our special day to show you!
author: Alexandra G.

description:
We recently got married on the 4th Floor North Gallery, and our day could not have been more amazing! The building itself is breathtaking. We wanted more of a wedding feel, so we reserved the 4th floor for an hour. 

We went the day before to get our license, and to check out the space since this was a destination wedding for us. Our license appointment was at 9am, and the building was pretty empty. We saw some people heading in to get married as we left around 10:00. The process to get the license was fast at that time, but we wanted to walk around and see the building. You have to make an appointment to get your license online.

If you do a quick civil ceremony, they usually do it in the Rotunda, which is beautiful. You can have 6 guests, but it will be in a public area. If you want something more private, you can reserve one of the 4th floor galleries or the mayor's balcony for a fee. You can rent chairs for guest too. We chose the 4th floor North gallery because the lighting is better.

On the day of your wedding, they will rope off the area that you reserve, so it is a little more private. There were some people trying to catch a peak, but they could not wander in. City Hall allows for a string duo (not a quartet) if you would like string music. We hired Corelli Strings, and they were amazing. You also have to bring your own officiant. We chose Cynthia Gregory who set a beautiful tone to our ceremony. We also worked with our photographer Amanda Wei (Blueberry Photography) and HItmaker Films. They all have experience at City Hall and do a great job. 

City Hall gave us the feel that we wanted in a beautiful setting without all of the fuss. We got married around noon. I was told it was empty during that time, but there were some people around. If you want a chance to get the iconic staricase photos, you may want to consider early morning or late afternoon. The later the better. One more tip, make sure about your time and your date. It is the government, and you cannot change things around without losing your deposit. If you will have a photographer, video, or ceremony music, you may want to contact them to confirm availability before committing to a date.
author: Keli B.

description: Wow this place is beautiful inside. We were invited to a wedding here and our first thought was why fly across the country to get married at city hall. After visiting I see why. Definitely worth a quick visit just to see how beautiful the building is.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Such a nice building, surrounded by junkies and shit (human feces) outside.
author: Ricardo O.

description:
It's been a little over a year since my husband and I exchange our vows on the 4th floor balcony. If you want a no fuss, no stress kind of civil wedding, SF City Hall is definitely the place. With its beautiful architecture and majestic staircase, its perfect backdrop makes any picture breathtaking! 

If you decide to have a separate private ceremony, I would advise getting your marriage license the day before your official wedding day. I did, and it made my life so much easier! In retrospect, I would also advise you to book your ceremony during the lunch hour. The building is almost literally empty and photos come out great. Wish I had! 

Not even going to lie about this one, I don't know where parking is cuz I used Uber to pull up in my wedding dress lol!
author: Sheryl K.

description:
Come here to pay taxes in person and other events such as flu vacations. The security is so inconsistent. I can come in one day by just putting my keys and phone in the tray before walking through the gates, other days I would be asked to remove my belt and jacket. One time they were even asking for my shoes which had no metal.

Nowadays there always protestors somewhere. Then there are also families getting married who are inconsiderate to others. But that is just part of being in the city.
author: M C.

description:
This more like a museum rather than a city hall! There is so much to look at and the building is beautiful. Hard to believe that SF has a city hall this magnificent. It's truly a site to behold. 

Came here yesterday in hopes to get our marriage license, but foolhardy me didn't realize you need an appointment and they are book for almost the entire month! Sad face. Still, they were somewhat nice about, but there was a dude picking his nose while helping us. Kinda weird. 

It's a huge building and worth of a visit. It's part of history folks!
author: Benny H.

description:
We got married here! Do we regret it? Absolutely not. Was the experience as great as everyone is saying? Maybe not so much. 

First, the process is somewhat confusing. We arrived half an hour early with license already in-hand (hint: it's cheaper to get it at another courthouse!), but still spent most of that time running around trying to figure out where to take a number and whether we were supposed to take a number (yes). We had a friend who is a photographer doing our pictures and serving as our witness, but if we didn't, we definitely would have hired one of these photographers who is familiar with the process - highly recommended for others.

Secondly, on a random Monday in March, the place was SWAMPED. I expected a lot of tourists, but I didn't expect a photographer "camped out" at every little nook and in front of every beautiful scene "reserving" the territory for another bride. Rude. People are also super disrespectful of the 6-guest limit - right before we got married, there was a group of at least 20 taking formal portraits on the stairs!  

That being said, once we found the right place to be, the whole process was like being at a very efficient DMV. Everything was on-time and ran smoothly. Our commissioner, Mary, was super sweet. We were not offered a "traditional" vs. "secular/modern" ceremony as many report, but seem to have automatically received the latter, which was very nice and unique. She was great at guiding us through the ceremony and letting us take our time, and was also very careful to pronounce our (rather difficult) names correctly. And while it did require a fair bit of pushiness, we were able to get some very nice pictures inside. 

All-in-all, not a bad experience - and perfect for what my husband and I wanted - but I'm kind of shocked that people travel to CA just for this experience!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
The City Hall of SF!! I remember driving by this area last year and remembering the astonishing  views of this neighbourhood, but never getting the chance to get off the car to walk around this neighbourhood.

The outside of the City Hall has two rows of English Knobby Syncamore trees that are cut down during the winter time and makes it look like you're walking around the City Hall around Halloween season. Despite the look of these trees, the City Hall of San Francisco still maintains a grand and royal appearance, especially at night time where the roof of the City Hall turns blue.

It appears as though many people come here for a wedding celebration in San Francisco! I wonder if you have to be married or attending a wedding to go inside the City Hall!
author: Kristy N.

description:
I was seriously impressed by this City Hall. The architecture outside is jaw-dropping and very intricate. 
When I was there, I got off the tour bus to explore. There was a wedding being held, so it was fun to see pictures being taken. 
The whole structure looks very grand and blows other city's city halls out of the water!
author: Amelia J.

description: Had our wedding here at it was quick, beautiful, and easy. We wanted a nice ceremony and dinner reception after and this place made it a very memorable moment.
author: Ricky V.

description:
Get married at one of the Top 10 Most Beautiful City Halls in the U.S.? I couldn't imagine it any other way!

The first day I set foot in this building, I knew it was where I wanted my intimate wedding. Fast forward to 3 weeks ago on a Saturday afternoon, building closed off to the public, my dreams came true. 

I had goosebumps while I waited on the 2nd floor of the Rotunda. Corelli Strings Trio started playing John Legend's All of Me and that was my cue. Walking down the Grand Staircase was EVERYTHING. For all of you who have watched Cinderalla (No, not the remakes. Yes, the ORIGINAL 1950s film) - now I know how she feels! Though my shoe didn't fall off and I had a modern day pumpkin carriage - UberLUX. Lol :) That and seeing my fiance/PRINCE CHARMING (because I made my own damn disney movie), our family and closest friends waiting for me at the bottom of the stairs in tears, will definitely be a memory that will last a LIFETIME! 

Thanks City Hall for being my happiest place on earth that day!
author: Erika D.

description:
Do not visit San Francisco it is dirty! 
somebody just took a crap right in front of us!
1142 Eddy Street San Francisco. Good morning everyone...!
all these diseased disgusting people defecating and we suppose to feel compassionate? How about fencing off the city and have it all quarantined? 

Ivan
author: Ivan S.

description: Everytime I'm in SF, my daughter wants to take me to see the City Hall. She raves about how beautiful it is. So we finally made it this time while I was there, just two days ago. We get there, and the doors were locked. We checked the hours, it was supposed to have been Open. Disappointed of course. Maybe Next Time.
author: Asma P.

description: It's a very beautiful place.. Went there once for a wedding shoot. Btw I am a photographer and do events like weddings, parties, maternity , family sessions etc. Prices are very reasonable and would love to shoot you. Contact me if your are interested.
author: Aditi K.

description:
OMG San Francisco city hall is so beautiful! It's located very close to the bart station, so it's very convenient if you are coming from outside sf with bart. 

On the day I came in, there were a lot of couples taking their massage photos here. I totally didn't expect this to happen lol. There was also a group of people dancing inside the city hall with their music on. What a surprise! Before coming, I thought this place gotta be very serious. Seems like it's the opposite. Of course, people still try to remain quiet, so you won't feel like you are walking into a market or something. 

I have moved to San Francisco for quite a while, and this is definitely an eye opener for me.
author: Lila L.

description: I have been officiating weddings at City Hall for a few years now. (californiaweddingofficiant.com) I never get tired of the stunning architecture and décor. Even though it is more than 100 years old it looks better than the day it was finished (thanks to a massive renovation in the 90's). I highly recommend it for casual elopements or lavish events. You can even stop by for a tour.
author: Andrew A.

description: I highly recommend getting married at City Hall's Fourth Floor North Gallery. Its not complicated, not expensive, and you get to take advantage of the spectacular architecture and details, and not to mention, the best natural lighting. I would recommend Amanda Wei Photography - she is well known at City Hall, knows how, when, and where to get the best photos.
author: Elisa C.

description: Best Staff! Had a flight delay and couldn't make it to my own wedding but they held my hand and helped me get fit-in when I landed (SFO) before the office even opened!!! They went above and beyond and I cannot thank them enough.
author: Katherine C.

description:
My sister and her husband recently had their wedding ceremony here. It's still a beautiful, well-kept venue. It was just how I remembered it from my junior prom back in my high school days. The ceremony was beautiful, which is all I could ask for for my sister on her special day. We were just bombarded by angry protester outside of the building after the ceremony, which really rubbed me the wrong way. Instead of taking photos directly outside of City Hall, since they kept getting in the way and were extremely annoying, we just decided to do the photo shoot across the street.

Besides the rude protesters, I still love this place!
author: Paulamertha A.

description:
I came here for a wedding ceremony and it was gorgeous.  The building has beautiful detail and even their bathrooms are gorgeous.  

If you have a backpack you'll have to enter through a side door that has an x-ray machine.  

Even on an average Tuesday the place has tourists coming through and couples getting married.  If you're coming for photos be sure to get here early, less crowds and beautiful lighting.
author: Mary N.

description: It's alright, average speed not as bad as a dmv beautiful place to get married and take lots of pictures inside or outside.
author: Specky T.

description: Very beautiful and well run! Had an appointment with the fiancé and we were actually taken in early! Parking around the area was a breeze as well!
author: Karen L.

description:
San Francisco City Hall - I was invited to be the witness of a very spontaneous wedding of a friend of mine, and gosh, that place is beautiful. From the outside - impressive and one of the city's landmarks. On the inside - even more gorgeous. There are no words that can describe the beautiful views you get from every single angle, and the thankfulness you'll feel when you're standing on the wide stairs.

Thankful for the city to host such a wonderful landmark, and in my case, thankful for being the wedding witness.

More to come!
author: Sebastian F.

description: When I heard my friend was going to get married at city hall I honestly wasn't expecting much. My local city hall in New Orleans is pretty run down and just not attractive. However, this place is beautiful both inside and out. Not to mention huge! So many places to take gorgeous pictures in and around the building. Being inside made me want to get married all over again! Absolutely stunning! As a bonus, the staff was very friendly and accomodating!
author: Ashley D.

description: Paying repect to a wonderful Mayor.  R.I.P. ED LEE.   SAN FRANCISCO LOVES YOU.....There will never be another you!
author: Janet T.

description:
My visit to Vital Records was 15 minutes well spent. 

I'm so glad I came in person vs mailing in my request which would've taken an estimated 10 business days to process 
+ a required notarized application; 
+ a self addressed stamped return envelope 
+ a $30 expedite fee;
IN ADDITION TO the $25 Record Search Fee to produce a certified copy of the Birth Certificate. 

Vital Records is in Rm 162, 1st Flr @ City Hall where Birth / Death certificates are processed while you wait. We were in and out in under 15 minutes, with a certified copy in hand. 

REDUCE YOUR WAIT: 
Download the form online, complete it, and print prior to coming to City Hall. However, do NOT complete part II of the Sworn Statement (page 2), the remaining information must be notarized or completed in the presence of SF County Clerk Vital Records Staff;

BRING VALID GOVT ISSUED PHOTO ID and one of the following METHODS OF PAYMENT: check payable to "SF County Clerk", or debit card (pin required), or cash ("exact change" only);

TIMING IS EVERYTHING: Last fully completed application accepted no later than 3:50pm, Monday through Friday (closed federal holidays). 

ADDITIONAL INFO: 
Email county.clerk@sfgov.org

Or visit their official site
http://www.sfgov2.org/index.aspx?page=3330
author: Geminyna J.

description:
Best place hands down to have your wedding ceremony! 

My husband and I got married here on Dec 2nd of this year and were so pleased with the whole process. It was quick and simple and very memorable. 

The best part was the amazing pictures we got. The whole place was like a dream Christmas wedding. We still can't stop talking about how gorgeous the pictures turned out and how happy we are that we chose such a stunning place to get married. 

Lastly, they let us have all of our bridal party and family members there-almost 20 people! We got to get married by the huge Christmas tree with all of our loved ones right by us. It was truly a dream come true  The judge was patient and kind, and made it a special moment we will never ever forget! 

Thank you SF City Hall for making our day so lovely! 
Love Laura and Jekyns Pelaez
author: Laura A.

description:
The most beautiful and elegant city hall I've seen. 
Perfect for engagement and  wedding photos. 
Fantastic architecture, be sure to stay outside for at least  a bit to look and take in all the beauty. 
Metal detectors and checking of bags is a must at entrance. 
There are entrances on both sides (van ness and other at Polk). If you have large oversized bags, enter on the side. Many don't know but There is a separate entry for that. . Or just go to regular entrance and they will direct you to go around
author: Veranna N.

description: Gorgeous place to get married! If you are driving please give yourself enough time to find parking. Sometimes it can be difficult to find around here.
author: Janet L.

description: We had our holiday party in here and it was pretty magical. Granted i don't know what city hall is like in he inside, besides the day I came to vote and was in the hot basement. But the staircase was very grand, and almost felt like a place of royalty. If you are only in San Francisco for the weekend, I would drive by, but there are cooler attractions. With that though, City Hall is pretty dope
author: Ross S.

description:
I've always dreamed of getting married in a gorgeous place with a huge staircase, like something from a Disney movie.  So after exhausting our options in SF, my husband asked me where I've always imagined getting married at.  I quickly responded City Hall.  The reason I had never mentioned it was because of the cost.  It's expensive (unless you just hold the civil ceremony there, which is free).  My husband crunched some numbers and after all of the hidden costs for security etc etc knew we couldn't afford it.  However, he found out that we could pay less to rent out the space for 2 hours for a private ceremony, which is what we did.

Our interactions with the office staff were rather disappointing.  It took a long time for email correspondences and to get answers when we had questions.  For the price you pay, you would think you'd receive better customer service, but I didn't care.  I just really wanted to walk down the aisle at City Hall.

On the day of, the staff were surprisingly really nice.  One of them offered me water as I waited to walk down the aisle.  He was a savior at that point, since I had forgotten to eat lunch and was incredibly thirsty.  He even found me a chair to sit down on while the bridal party procession took place.  Everything went smoothly and the venue was exactly what I wanted.  It was stunning, and nearly every guest commented on the beauty of SF City Hall.  Would I pay that amount of money again?  Definitely!  This building is one of the most breath-taking sites of San Francisco.  The grand staircase, the marble floors, the artistry... It's magnificent.  It was my dream wedding come true.
author: Penny N.

description: If you want to get married on a budget, this place is more than perfect.  You can rent one of the floors for $1k for an hour to have an intimate and semi-private ceremony.  We rented the 4th floor North gallery and were able to host about 35 of our closest friends and family.  The building is absolutely beautiful so your photos will come out stunning.  Picking this place to have our ceremony was one of the best decisions we made for our wedding day.  The people that work in the events department are very responsive by email so they made the whole process very stress free.
author: Jenn W.

description:
This is a great building with beautiful architecture.   I have toured it a couple of times with the free City Guides (check them out if your a tourist)  They tell you about the building and the history of the area.   The two tours I did were quite different due to different guides.   '

It is also a center of activities,  I have been buy when everything from protests to the Dew Tour were going on.   The area is usually busy.
author: Mark B.

description: Very gorgeous building, especially beautiful lighting at nights. Dawn visit would be good for both daylight and after sunset.
author: Maruko X.

description:
Whilst venturing around the downtown SF area, we just had to make a stop at City Hall. This place was not hard to find, but finding parking nearby is a pain in the neck. We lucked out, and found parking adjacent to the building as someone was pulling out. 
Getting in here involves having to go through a metal detector. Once through, we were free to roam the large place and it's two stories. There were several displays, including a scale model of the building, a heart shaped panel of names of same-sex married couples, a big Christmas tree, and holiday decorations. Somewhere here is the office of the mayor, but due to the fact that we were here after normal business hours, he was not home. The hallways that make up the first and second floor are great to walk around, although just about all doors found along the hallways are locked. 
The best sight within this place is the giant Christmas tree. It is decorated pretty well, and provides a beautiful centerpiece in an otherwise boring interior. The outside of the building is decorated in different lighting schemes, depending on the time of year or the occasion. There is a large lawn in front of the building, and there are many hippy groups always protesting or just loitering here.
I'd recommend checking this place out during the holiday season.
author: William G.

description: We were getting super stressed out about having a big wedding so we decided to have our own private moment and throw a big party at a later date. We were married on the Mayor's balcony yesterday June 13th by Judge Tom! This was a truly delightful experience, I highly recommend it! Don't stress, do it for yourselves!
author: Anne P.

description:
I got married here
It was a very simple process 
We came in a few days before to fill out some forms and we got married on a Thursday 
The ceremony was less than ten minutes and was great
author: Kelly A.

description: I've been to many special events and weddings here, and it's just a BEAUTIFUL location! The architecture and design is so pretty and it's well maintained. I always love seeing how they light it up at night for special occasions (holidays and sports).
author: Jennifer J.

description:
I can't imagine why everyone doesn't just tie the knot here! It's gorgeous and even though there are thousands of tourists and visitors on a daily basis, try and stick around til about 4-430 so you can have the entire rotunda and stairs to yourselves.  After all the anxiety waiting and the treacherous ceremony waiting.....it pays to have a moment to yourselves of course with your Wedding Photographer ..... capture and freeze that moment forever.

Happy 100th Birthday City Hall, you have made many many many people very happy and will continue to do so for many years and generations to come!
author: Bahvee V.

description:
Politics aside, City Hall itself is a great venue space.  My company had our Holiday Party here and it was a nice classic environment with the intricate architecture, the elaborate design of everything from the ceilings to the wall fixtures, and well, too many more things to describe.  Of course, with it being so wide open, it made it hard to find people.  I think I literally climbed up and down those stairs three times and I wasn't entire sober either so I was very conscious of where my feet landed because it was a looooong way down to the bottom of the stairs.

The only downside to coming here is walking through the shady from the Civic Center BART station.  I think I Uber'd in and out on the night I came in.  If you're walking to BART at night, then make sure to walk in pairs for safety.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Probably the most beautiful historic building in all of San Francisco, both inside and out, and it's free! 

I've done the tour before which is great for the history and seeing all the ins and outs, but frankly wandering about on your own is pretty great, too. 

It's beautiful in daytime and nighttime, and it's fun to watch the different wedding ceremonies going on. If you're looking to take pictures without a ton of random strangers, weekdays in the late afternoon are the way to go.
author: Kate K.

description: Didn't go inside, just got some Christmas color photos of the outside.  Nice looking city hall.
author: Tim L.

description:
Gorgeous place! We had such an amazing wedding here. We had the whole 9-yards.... the prettiest venue, a private wedding, strings players, etc... I would not change a thing! Our wedding and our photos are so beautiful! I don't have to go on and on about this, several people have posted already. 

I'd like to also mention the staff in the events department. We worked mostly with Quinn and Abby via email/phone. They were fantastic! So responsive and helpful, so huge thanks to them! Also, thanks to the people the day of who were making sure our wedding remained private. I'm not sure of their names, but they did a great job! I'd recommend this venue to anyone and everyone! 

Married at San Francisco City Hall 7/24/15.
author: Nicole G.

description: One of the prettiest city halls in the nation.  It's great to marvel at during the day and even at night when it's lit up.  It is open to the public only during the week so if you're planning on visiting, don't try on the weekends.  It's worth the visit because it's right across from the Civic Center Plaza, Asian Art Museum and the public library.
author: Anthony G.

description:
I had attended a wedding this past weekend in San Francisco, and I was totally caught off guard at how beautiful this historical building was..........

When I heard the couple was going to get married at "city hall" and not at a church, all I thought of was a small, fly by night, let's get married quick, small rinky dink place..........little did I know how beautiful and grand this place was!

The building is quite old, but well kept.....it looks like something that was built a long time ago, and I could see someone saying - ":they don't make things like that anymore".

The architecture of the building was definitely old school, there were large archways, and a stunning long staircase! This stunning landmark building probably has a long rich history, and I wished I took the time out to research this place before I came out here.

I came to City Hall  two days in a row, as the 1st day was spent attending the wedding rehearsal (for a few hours), and the 2nd day was for the wedding. On the 1st day I was there, it was like a zoo............so many couples getting married here, I could see various couples - man & wife..........and man & man.

I was a bit concerned as I was thinking, "how is my family going to take any good photo's" with so many strangers walking around using the same facilities? 
With so many people using this place, it would be a great distraction for a small and intimate wedding. 

Later I found out, you can actually rent out the entire facility to make it a private function, but of course it is not free.........for a fee, you can have the entire place for yourself...........this is what the couple did for their wedding day. All worth it, for the money spent! I tell you, this was one of the most memorable wedding ceremonies that I ever attended.

There is a large underground parking structure, for private functions, there is a flat fee of $15.00 for parking, otherwise it's by the hour for a fee.

I also found out that they do have tours of the facility, but the tours only happen on the weekdays.........I did not get a chance to tour the entire building, but if I ever get a chance to come back, I will surely take the tour of this grand place!
author: Fran C.

description: I brought a large group here for a docent tour with Ellen Schumer. Ellen must retire. She is a cranky lady who does not enjoy giving tours whatsoever. She is the rudest person I have ever met. As a group leader, I do not recommend anyone getting tours here because Ellen is a genuinely mean person. I can't make that any more clear.
author: Dana D.

description:
I'm of two minds about the San Francisco City Hall.

One side of me swoons when I'm inside City Hall. It's a beautiful building which can be, in turns, bustling and joyful and quiet and solemn. I've had some great experiences here - weddings of friends. 

I've had some not-so-great experiences here - when I made an appointment to get my passport and they told my my appointment was invalid even though I had a confirmation. Argh.
author: Tara H.

description:
I love there with beautiful architecture ... You must attend free tour and tour guide will explain many details of the city hall.  

There are many couples taking pictures here and holding weddings. What a beautiful place!
author: Ruby C.

description: I attended a wedding here for my friend, and I acted as the witness. It is a beautiful place to host a wedding with beautiful Roman-like architecture and sculpture inside the City Hall. The overall wedding took less than 1.5 hours to finish. A judge would wed the husband and wife at the top of the staircase. Family and friends would frantically take photos during this time. Overall it was so fun to attend a wedding at he City Hall. I think it is a wonderful service that they provide. A few tips on how to enter the building without any issues: you would need to enter from the side if you have any bags or backpacks as the front can only allow small items to pass through the security.
author: Sam K.

description:
Message to Edwin Lee:  Stun guns are not the answer. The citizens of San Francisco DO NOT NEED one more weapon in the hands of the SFPD. Edwin Lee, you are being stupidly short sighted. Edwin Lee, your actions will set the City of San Francisco up for lawsuits. Will you, Edwin Lee, Gavin Newsom & Willie Brown be paying for these lawsuits that will come if you arm our police with stun guns????  Where was Willie Brown at the recent town hall meeting in Bayview?  Where were you, Edwin Lee????

The residents and voters of San Francisco will not support further violence against our citizens.  Edwin Lee, your sneaky tactics of trying to push stun guns through the SFPD during the christmas holiday IS WRONG. Literally DEAD WRONG.

Edwin Lee, you think you have a fight on your hands, sir?  You have no idea what you're in for if you try to pass this.
author: Alacrity I.

description:
I'm a structural engineer and people often ask me what my favorite building. Well, hands down San Francisco City Hall. It's just breathtaking on the inside and outside -- the architectural and interior design. I highly recommend visiting if you have not done so. 

It's a multi-use facility so there are city public offices and sam tag working during normal hours, along with photographers, tourists, and soon-to-be-newly weds taking picture all over. 

The fourth floor is my favorite hiding spot. I'm just in love with the way the natural lighting shines through the windows and hits the marble floors and walls.  

I love my beautiful city. I can't believe I work right next door to this magnificent building. City Hall is absolutely my all time favorite building in the world.
author: Ellen W.

description:
I love beaux arts style architecture!  It really symbolizes a time when things were lovingly made to last and it won't crumble (ahem new Bay Bridge aka Brown/Brown monstrosity, Made in China garbage).  This is really the most fantastic building in all of SF!  If you have friends visiting, definitely take them to City Hall.  They have free docent led tours on the weekdays.  

I went with the Kid's class and we got a tour of the whole building - including the board of supervisor's chambers, which looked remarkably orange and sans the inmates that run the asylum and Big Ed's reception area.  

Really it's like standing inside a big giant wedding cake.  The soaring ceilings just takes your breath away.
author: Wendy H.

description:
I have worked here in San Francisco in the Civic Center area (State Building) since January 2007 and have never set foot in City Hall until today. 

I have been in Alameda and Oakland City Halls, and I must say nothing compares to the grand style of San Francisco City Hall...the architectural design is impeccable and it's definitely a beautiful landmark inside and out, and in a class by itself.  It is elegance at its best.  I am so looking forward to my nephew's wedding in August here at City Hall.

What brought me here this afternoon?  It was a special day and I thank Mayor Ed Lee for pulling a quick one over the City of Oakland in honoring Golden State Warriors Stephen Curry and proclaiming this day as Stephen Curry Day.  A young fifth grade student (photo) from a school in the Tenderloin delivered the speech and presented the key to the city to Curry.  I didn't get a Warriors T-shirt, but just being there it was all good.
author: Carol C.

description:
One of the most beautiful places in San Francisco to have a quick romantic civil wedding. The building is so historic and gorgeous! Perfect place to take pictures as well. 

I was fortunate enough to witness sone really good friends elope. They took their vows on the grand staircase and it was just absolutely beautiful. 

The process was very quick and the judge was the absolute sweetest.

Everything about this place was just perfect.
author: Dee E.

description:
I got married here on 09/26/2014 and it was actually my very first time visiting the inside of City Hall! The building itself is BEAUTIFUL and I loved the grand staircase. Just a note to anyone who want to get married here in the future: MAKE SURE YOU GO ONLINE AND SCHEDULE AN APPOINTMENT FOR BOTH THE MARRIAGE LICENSE *AND* THE CEREMONY ITSELF!! You don't necessarily have to do both appointments on the same day, but that's what I did. I scheduled my marriage license appointment at 9AM and the ceremony at 10AM.

My husband (that's still a little weird calling him that HAHA) and I rode BART over to City Hall because of the time frame we had, we did not want to sit in traffic to be late for our appointments. Smartest thing we ever did, to be honest. Made it with 20 minutes to spare before our marriage license appointment. The only thing I didnt like was that the doorway to the office was a bit hidden, but other than that, the appointment went by so quick. 

As for the ceremony, it was done at the grand staircase in front of all the tourists haha. I actually did not mind this because I never noticed the tourists. All I could focus on was my husband and telling each other our vows and exchanging our rings. Even in such an open and public setting, I still had the intimate ceremony I wanted. I practically cried saying my vows. The officiant was very funny and personable and made me feel like the bride I was that day. I loved every bit of my ceremony and I would not change it for anything in the world.
author: Chantelina J.

description: I literally have no experience here except walking by it to take a few photos, but... it's awesome. I always love seeing city halls and this one is stunning!
author: Justine J.

description:
While on vacation, we visited city hall. Since when is city hall in any city a tourist stop? It is when city hall is like a state capitol building.

The rotunda was taller than expected and the gold gilding truly accented the building with class. A history of city hall is found in the South Light Court and there is a public art gallery on the basement floor level. Allow 30 minutes to visit.

You can also pretend to be Harrison Ford and Karen Allen at the end of "Raiders of the Lost Ark" while visiting DC bureaucrats or Clint Eastwood and Tyne Daly in "The Enforcer" when Dirty Harry tells the police commissioner what to do with his seven-star shield. Also in "The Enforcer", you'll see that there used to be a reflecting pond in front of City Hall (before they just casually stroll 2 miles to Coit Tower.)

I've written over 100 Yelps this year. I'm sure you want to see a list of those 100 places. NOT! And of course, you want my pointless list to appear in the "Related Lists" section of this business because the 100 places I visited this year are 100% irrelevant to this business.
author: Brian U.

description: I didn't have enough time to go inside the building but it definitely felt like it was the center of town, nestled in with other government and public offices as well as the Asian Art Museum. Really beautiful architecture. It is bordering the Tenderloin area which does seem a little shadier during odd times of the day so perhaps better to do during working hours if you're a tourist. But a standard city hall-style building when compared to other major cities around the country.
author: Vikram V.

description:
The civil wedding that we had there was magic!

The staff is friendly and very organized - through the application process we hardly had to wait in line. The justice that married us was a wordsmith and a highly spirited gentleman. 

It really is as good as it gets
author: An A.

description: Absolutely gorgeous.  A great landmark.  If you like to take photo with architectural building then this a place for you. Does not open on weekend.
author: Ngoc K.

description:
I can't believe that I never reviewed this place! Ah! Yelpers, I must tell you the story of the worst wedding ever (it was mine.) 

January 14, 2010. It is a Thursday morning. I have been up all night sewing an alternative back into my wedding dress. After two hours of sleep, it's time to get up and head to the courthouse to get married. This is already a disaster waiting to happen. 

I get dressed and grab my makeup to do in the car. Driving from the East Bay to SF on a weekday morning is asking for trouble. We need to leave now.

I know this is a mistake. I've been engaged for two years. We own a big house. We have pets. How am I going to get out of this? I'm not. There's a cancelation fee of less than $100 so clearly there is no turning back now. I'm 22 years old and I am dumb enough to think any of the aforementioned reasons, and especially the cancelation fee, are a true barrier to not ruining my life. 

I look down at my hand. I love my engagement ring. I don't want to wear any other piece of jewelry with it ever. I'm glad I decided against a wedding band. I feel like this is partially a good reason to go ahead and keep on toward City Hall. What was I thinking? 

Only 6 people are allowed to attend the ceremony because it's a courthouse. My family doesn't approve and they're not there. Oh well, we're both the oldest of four so I guess it works out - we'll just have my fiance's two friends be our witnesses that we are required to bring.

Well if this day couldn't get any more stressful, my fiance decides he's brining my least favorite person in the universe to City Hall - his overbearing Russian matriarch grandma. Kill me. We have to pick her up before we get to City Hall.

She criticizes my shoes. She also tells us that we're going to get divorced (she was right) & tells me I'm going to wear a family ring as my wedding band. I don't feel comfortable wearing a small car-priced ring. Plus it's hideous. Ugh.

We get to City Hall. Everyone oohs and awws over us as we walk inside. Grab a number and wait to be called.

As I lean against the pillars, I can't help but notice how stunning this place is. At least I'm getting married in the most gorgeous non-religious place I've ever been. 

After walking the halls with one of our witnesses for over an hour, our number is called. Thank God because I can't listen to his grandma nag me for another second.

Surprisingly the rooms off the main hall are like every DMV in America. We go from station to station stamping and signing documents. I'm so screwed. The papers are signed, technically I'm married. They give us a packet about sexual health. This is weird. 

There are other people getting married so we have to wait our turn to get married in the rotunda. Everyone looks so pretty. I feel sad. 

Our number is up. The officiant starts to speak. I zone out. What am I doing?

"Do you Stephanie..." "What? My name's not Stephanie" I blurt out. The officiant reads my last name wrong and presumably thought it was my first name. This is so embarrassing. If they say the wrong name does that void the legality of the wedding?

It's time for the vows. "Thank you so much, I'm his grandmother. I am from Russia and I live..." Is this b---- really interrupting my wedding to tell the officiant about herself? "Excuse me, can we finish this? It's not over" I can't hide the vitriol in my voice between my clenched teeth. And why is she standing right next to him? I hate everything about this moment.

I don't understand why only 6 people can attend when there is an Asian bus tour surrounding us and taking pictures of us throughout the 10 minute ceremony. 

I high five my new husband when it's over. I hate my life. Apparently this was the cue for the tour to stand in line to take pictures with us holding up the peace sign. At least they have pictures because I don't. Not that I'd want them.

I am absolutely seething at his grandma. Of all times to stunt... On my ill-advised wedding day?! The officiant tells us we can get a copy of our license later but she has another ceremony to do.

God this place is pretty. It's actually breathtaking. I wish for a thousand things to be different but at least I picked such a gorgeous location. It's a beautiful disaster.

It's after 3. Traffic is going to be a nightmare. We have to be at our reception dinner with his whole family at 6 in Pleasanton.

My new husband (who is 27) decides it's a better idea to drive to South SF to wait out the traffic playing Call of Duty with his friends that accompanied us. It's totally necessary too because they're spending the night at our house after our dinner so that they can keep playing the game. We were so late. FML.

5 months to the day I decide I can't take a second longer of this and leave.

The only good thing about the marriage was the  gorgeous City Hall.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Granted I only have a handful of Government agencies to compare to, but SF City Hall has to be one of the most gorgeous facilities around. Sure it's not the Spanish Guggenheim or the Taj Mahal, but It's beautiful, it's curvy, it's refined, and it's omnipresent from just about any elevated vista throughout town. SF City Hall is basically the Beyonce of Government domiciles whose HOA fees come from the tax paying public, while just about every other government branch resembles the entire cast of Mob Wives. Woof! 

While the image of getting married at any city's City Hall seems like an unromantic journey into holy matrimony, it's different at SF City Hall. In fact, you'd be hard pressed to find a more whimsical, inspiring destination to complete your nuptials with the person you want to spend the rest of your life with. It's such an amazing gift to residents of San Francisco to have something like this. Being able to celebrate one of the most significant days of your life in an architectural marvel surrounded by love and equality is about as good as it gets.

I live in New York, but my heart will always be in San Francisco. The current political uneasiness surrounding tenant rights, chronic homelessness, and countless other issues notwithstanding... this very building is one of many reasons to feel proud about being a San Franciscan.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
I was expecting a rundown Victorian Hall. San Francisco is a very old city. Lots of landscapes, homes and neighborhoods are pretty run down and need some major facelift. So, I expected the same for the City Hall.

When I drove around this Hall, I was very impressed. Even though it was in the late evening, I can see that they kept the streets and roads clean around this location. And up kept the Roman decor on the outside very well. I was very interested on how it looked on the inside.

I walked up those narrow steps and under Roman designed columns and into a room where you walk through a metal detector. From there, you walk into a hall way where it leads to other several other halls.

The main hall is in the center of the whole building. It's beautiful. I felt like I was in a Roman arena about to battle it out with gladiator... if the long stair case wasn't in the way hehee

There smaller halls on the left and right and also behind this center. They are smaller compared to the main hall, but their still long and large and impressive.

I hope to visit this hall again during the day time or maybe even the opportunity to squeeze in a photo shoot. That would be a dream =)
author: Cathy N.

description:
Beautiful place to come, wedding ceremony or not. The lighting and grandeur here are really remarkable and photograph beautifully. I've seen brides in full on gowns and simple dresses here, either way it works. The rotunda is a perfect place for pictures and the staircase is epic as well. 

You can do a lot of your paperwork, make appointments and pay fees online. Be sure to plan and book ahead, especially if you want a special date/time or on a holiday (Valentine's Day or Halloween). Come early! 

There is a parking garage close by.
author: Bianca U.

description: We went to a wedding here a few years ago and it was beautiful! It's always a good place to go when there are big events happening in SF. Dreamforce was held here a couple years ago and it was a lot of fun. Worth checking out!
author: Autumn Y.

description: Most embarrassing building in San Francisco. You ever walk in front of this building at night? Jesus! The amount of homeless people in front of it reminds me of The Walking Dead. People yelling, fighting, shooting up, camped out, urinating or defecting, selling stolen goods, and even having oral sex in public. It's so embarrassing. The city's homeless problem has gotten dramatically worse and it's right in front of their building. You can literally hand he city a blank check to fix the homeless problem, but bet you that blank check it won't.
author: John D.

description: It is indeed a beautiful City Hall, it is no wonder it is so popular for weddings and special events.  My little brother decided to have his wedding here and we walked all over during the photo shoot.  It was my first visit at City Hall and I was a bit surprised that you had to go through a metal detector but luckily it was a weekday so we went through it rather quickly.  I don't want to even imagine how crazy it gets during weekends with big weddings and tons of family.  Parking is quite a challenge so i highly suggest getting there about 30+ mins. earlier OR in the alternative, bring walking shoes.  It is so beautiful that it is worth the hassle though.
author: Lina H.

description:
This place is a must go to architectural landmark. 

SFO's City Hall looks more important than SoCal's Long Beach City Hall that looks like an LA County Jail building.

Not only it looks beautiful from the outside but inside the renaissance style satisfies the eyes. Its nice to have a civil wedding here (which my wife and I plan to have on our 25th wedding anniversary) because this place is just freaking gorgeous.

Look at the steps, the marbled floors, the arts and structures, amazing! When we went inside it felt like a pure tourist spot and professional photo spot. Also we saw couples getting married.

Its nice to come here during the winter holidays too. Inside they have a large christmas tree on display. Check this place out during the nights, the dome lights up.
author: Jon B.

description:
The worst to come here and open business you will be online for 50 m to one hour .
All this big place with 2 employes only !!!!
author: Osi F.

description: Absolutely stunning! Such a gorgeous place for my husband and I to get married at! At the moment, we didn't have much time to plan nor funds to have a huge church wedding but we did, however, drove all the way from SoCal to experience what was the most amazing ceremony ever. SF City Hall is just so beautiful it's self that little planning was involved! We got married at the top of the grand stair case in the Rotunda! We loved every single detail about it! Our family took so many breath taking photos that we were slightly late for our private reception/ lunch. Since my husband is in the military we were able to receive our marriage certificate the day of but we had to head over to the restaurant. We came back the next day and they were able to help us out and request for the certificate the same day. The staff in the office were very kind and sweet! A big thank you to Morgan and Gabe for everything. You made our special day that more special!!! We will definitely come back to visit and say hello!
author: J M.

description: Do not get married here if you want your marriage certificate anytime soon. We are facing a greater than 1 month delay (usual time is 10 days) because the secretary made a typing error (yes, they still use typewriters here) and was too lazy to make a new form, so she decided to use white-out correction liquid. The paperwork is now deemed unacceptable, and these people should have known better. This is causing us all sorts of headaches with getting health insurance coverage and with immigration issues. The worst part is that, even though we did nothing wrong, the people in the clerk's office offer no apologies and seem unwilling to do anything to help expedite getting our certificate.
author: Andy B.

description:
Came here for a tour and I was SHOCKED that parking was SOOO easy. 
Bunch of spots for 4 hours max @ $3/hear.  More than enough space.  

Really didn't need to stress about BARTing in or parking all the way over at Chinatown 

Anyways, the City Hall tour was AWESOME but it would be perfect if they did it on the weekend too.
author: David W.

description:
As a San Francisco wedding photographer, I absolutely LOVE City Hall.  Every wedding I photograph here always turns out amazing with stunning images.  I am in love with you, City Hall.  :)
www.meganmoura.com
author: Megan M.

description:
This place is beautiful and the people working in there are even more wonderful. They're very helpful and nice!

I've been here for many occasions, 3 times for weddings, once for my own engagement photos, and once to get my address and voters information switched over.

For engagement/wedding photos I recommend coming in at the evening- it's super quiet and empty. The bathrooms are cleaned and empty for your use to change or touch up make up.. and the guards in front are so nice and are so happy to see you! :D Thank you!
author: Terinna R.

description:
I got married here over a week ago & like a lot of people have said...this place is BEAUTIFUL! I've lived in the Bay Area for most of my life & this was the first time I went to City Hall. 

We got married on a Friday, so there were a lot of people getting married. We were running a little bit late, so I was a little anxious about going through security & finding the office we needed to go to, to get our marriage certificate. 

I recommend giving yourself some extra time to get to City Hall to park, go through security (which was actually quick - I thought it would be like TSA at the airport, but it was pretty chill) & to find the office you need. 

The day we got married there was some weird interpretive dance by the staircase, which was weird, but I was not surprised since it is SF! When we left, there were a ton of cops outside because they were afraid of May Day protests coming in. I support protesters for the most part, but I'm glad they were not in City Hall when I was getting married.

A few other things to remember - if you're getting married, hire a professional photographer who knows the in & outs of City Hall. Our photographer City Hall Wedding Photographer was great & compared to other packages that I've seen, their prices were reasonable. 

Last thing - bring water & tissue! It was a hot day so we were sweating & I needed water & tissue, especially during our photo shoot.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Cranky pants moment caused by the clerk and the wedding division. I'm in the records research business. How about instead of making the public wait in line twice, once to get the form and then second time to submit form, you make forms available at a counter or in an obvious public area??????? We aren't all city workers jacking around until we get our fat pensions or about to plan our next workers' comp sabbatical. Some of us need to get the hell out and go on with business and our work days. 

1.6-hour trip that could have been done in 1/2-hour. Type of crap that makes us cynical about government. 

So I had to pay $15 to have the clerk do a search then he sent me down a hall and had to go into two offices to get information about a "confidential marriage." Clerk A could have handled all of this without having to involve clerks, B, C and D. Oh, and I had to pay other clerks a second time. 

Massively inefficient. Way to go local government.
author: Michael S.

description: I love architecture, so coming to this majestic place was a special treat. I did not even know it was open to the public until a friend mentioned it.  They call it the people's palace, and when you see it inside and out, you'll see why.
author: Ralph R.

description:
We made our appointment online, 3 hours apart for marriage license and ceremony. That was probably overkill, but that's what one website recommended. They are so amazingly efficient here, it totally did not take that long. Less than 10 minutes to get the license. But in the mean time, we waded into the park, had some amazing street truck food, and walked over to the Asian Art museum that had the terra cotta soldiers! 

We had beautiful non-denominational vows, nowhere did I vow "to obey", no "death to us part". None of that silliness. It was just lovely. The person who wed us volunteers to marry people! What a cool volunteer job!

We opted to get married in the veranda. It was amazing. Such a beautiful setting. It felt private despite being in a public place. 

-1 star to the state of California for not allowing gay marriage (this is after all, the former state capitol building)
author: Dea A.

description: I have done makeup and hair (Fox & Doll) for many brides that have been married at San Francisco City Hall, and I have attended a few weddings of friends. City Hall is one of my favorite wedding spots, very romantic and photographs beautiful with amazing light! I would recommend SF City Hall to couples seeking a special spot to do a low key elopement.
author: Shana A.

description: San Francisco's city hall makes me proud to say that I'm from the Bay Area. It's absolutely gorgeous. I've been here twice. Once with a friend and once for prom. The architecture of the building is amazing. There is so much work that's put into the making of this building and it's evident in the details and the layout of everything. It's three levels of gorgeous. I think the upper levels are reserved for government business. My friend and I accidentally wandered to the top thinking we'd find a better view. Anyways, when I went with my friend, there were several wedding photo shoots taking place. It's pretty adorable to see elegant brides and grooms waltzing around the halls. City hall is a must visit whether you are a local or a tourist.
author: Mindy Y.

description: Have been here for my son's wedding and a dear-friend's birthday party on the 4th of July.  This has to be one of the most beautiful, magical and interesting public buildings in the United States.   You will never forget your experience here.
author: Bill H.

description: Beautiful place to have a wedding. I was blown away by the decorum and building inside architecture.
author: Fred P.

description:
Where to begin. This is such a magnificent space. It's one worthy of a beautiful city such as San Francisco. From the majestic view of this massive structure from the outside to the rotunda and central staircase, it's a huge work of art. Take a stroll through the Mayor's balcony or 4th floor hallways. The place is lit from the huge windows facing south that allow natural light to filter through the space. 

I came around Christmas time so there was a beautiful tree at the top of the stairs. 

If you are getting married in California and want a small civil ceremony, there is no better place. I loved our officiant and they were very flexible about how many guests I could have there. Online, it says 6 only. I also found the clerk's office to be extremely responsive to emails. 

Take some time before and after the ceremony to take photos in the spaces. It can be crowded but you will be able to find some areas to take unforgettable photos. If you want to block off certain sections for your private photos you can pay I think $1k to reserve it. 

If you're just visiting SF, the Capital is not to be missed.
author: James W.

description: City Hall Tours are offered for free. Thought it was great service until we showed up. The tour guide mumbled, didn't move from one spot for over 30-minutes. We couldn't even hear him though there were only 7/8 people in the group. What kind of tour is that? It's a shame, but don't take the free tours with the tall blonde older gentleman. He was in his own world. So much for PR.
author: Cali G.

description:
What a beautiful venue - I got to scope out this place while standing witness to my friend's marriage ceremony. Much cleaner and more aesthetically pleasing than the one in NYC. It also made me laugh that there were a row of food trucks parked in front -- somehow, I doubt that would happen in other cities.

There's a lot going on right outside of City Hall, so if you plan to drive, allot some extra time to commute in.
author: Diana K.

description:
I once waited outside on the steps for my friends to arrive since we had a wedding rehearsal to attend here. Food trucks, peaceful strangers and sun rays with plenty of shaded areas for me to relax as I waited for my friends.

When they did, I opened the door and my high school friend was in a wedding dress! She had just gotten married! All of us are from the East bay so can you imagine how random that must've been for me. It was literally about a decade since I last saw her. I said my congrats and went inside with my other friends. The inside is gorgeous, so much detail to the walls. It was a little hot though. Now getting to the point, my friend married her love that weekend. Those steps were beautiful and I must say that the feeling I got from this hall was like an intimate vibe. A place that welcomes your very close family and friends.

Brings me good memories as I saw my own boyfriend slowly enter the building with his fine ass..... we could be next! Lol jk.

Job well done, SF.
author: Sweets N.

description: Beautiful architecture and supper clean, but nothing special about this building, they just come here and take a picture and go.
author: Steve Vu N.

description: San Francisco City Hall is one of the most beautiful buildings in the world. They take great pride in City Hall. In fact they are Leed certified. A huge, old building be they work so hard on making the world a better place. The workmanship and details of  City Hall are amazing. Stop by! You will not be disappointed!!
author: Lorinn S.

description:
Fun if you're a tourist.  If you come in here for business, you'll be here all day as the offices tell you to stand in one line, then the other, then back to the first.  Lost a whole day off productivity because people in the office can't correctly provide firms that the office across the hall needs.  Take three days off your business to get all the paperwork done to open your business.

Really annoying, get a supervisor to train offices next to each other what paperwork the other needs.

Fictitious name comes after business license, it just doesn't say so on state or city website.  The firm in question just literally was a woman writing my name in a firm to take office #2.
author: Levi H.

description:
Beautiful building representative of our city.

-Amazing architecture: beautiful exterior and interior with some questionable characters around
-Sometimes it's scruffy on the outside but definitely cleans up well
-A little high maintenance, but it's historically significant
-Very photogenic and classy; especially in everyone's wedding photos

And despite minor flaws, I think my City Hall is better than yours.
author: Missy X.

description:
I was at City Hall last night for my fiance's corporate holiday party and it was hands down the most stunning venue I have ever been in.  My mouth literally dropped when I saw the exterior all lit up (it was even Christmas colored), and then when we walked in I was further blown away by the incredible architecture.  You have to see it to fully appreciate its beauty and I highly recommend taking a stroll inside if you get the chance to.

If I were having a large event, this would 100% be on my list of places to try to book.  It is incredible, and the party inside was very fun too. :)
author: Alyx F.

description:
Some of the staff members working here are very friendly and helpful. Overall, positive experiences and excellent services here.
City Hall is a very beautiful San Francisco landmark and an excellent tourist attraction spot. The glorious interior and exterior is indeed a popular spot for wedding photo sessions. There are instances when I have seen couples holding their wedding ceremony at City Hall.

Bill Graham Civic Auditorium and Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall nearby!

Do you have property tax bills to pay for? But you don't want to mail in your property tax payment or pay online, paying in person at the office of the treasurer & tax collector is much more convenient.
Want to know more? Visit SF City Hall at the website provided below!
FYI, there are 4 security check points* as you enter!

*For annual property tax payments you can:
1) Mail in the stub and a check via USPS with the provided reply envelopes
2) Pay online via www.sfgov.org
3) Pay in person at City Hall*

A) Security checkpoint 1: (East Side) - Dr. Carlton B Goodlett Place entrance
B) Security checkpoint 2: (West Side) - Van Ness Ave entrance
C) Security checkpoint 3: (South Side) - Grove St entrance
D) Security checkpoint 4: (North Side) - McAllister St entrance

*Paying your property tax bill in person is preferred since you get a receipt.*

4/4/2013:
Most of the staff members here are very helpful, polite and friendly. The customer service here is very efficient.
author: Bennett W.

description: SF City Hall is beautiful. It's a great place to take photos, get married, or just explore history. They offer tours of City Hall throughout the week, just check with the desk in the lobby for current schedules.
author: Andrea V.

description:
Beautiful beautiful city hall!! The weddings gives joy and celebration, Sometime they have events there. Once i was lucky to see Peruvian dancing with costumes and singing at christmas time :)
Just a quit hall to find yourself in the middle of the busy city.
author: A A.

description:
We got married here today! It was really great! I'd like to add some more detail on how it all "goes down" since it isn't written about that much, other than the one other Yelp review (thank you, btw).

So we made our license appointment (10:30am) and then wedding ceremony (noon) reservations online. We parked in the city hall garage; it's $2.50 an hour, and there were lots of open spaces. We had to go to the second level down, but no biggie and we got a space by the elevator. I can see how that parking lot could get dirty, etc. but it was fine for us.

We went into city hall, through security (they were friendly), got directions to room 168. The building is stunning inside.

In terms of the line for room 168, when you get there, you see a line leading into the place, which you wait in if you don't yet have a number. The line moved along fine. We waited there, gave the license paperwork, and then we got a number. Because I'd printed out the license application at home, we had it filled out when we showed up--that saved us one iteration through the line. No more than 5 minutes later, maybe less, they were calling our number, and we got the license. 

Our CA drivers licenses were sufficient ID. We filed for a confidential license, and they didn't ask for any paperwork proving cohabitation (which we had just in case), they just took our word for it, although of course under oath.

So then we got the license, and they said show up 5 minutes before noon and get another ticket. We went to chill at the spacious cafe (the bathroom is by here too), and chatted with our photographer. Had some time to take rotunda photos before our ceremony, and Royce from Blurred Line (BlurredLine?) Photography rocked it for us. We actually decided to get photos done at the last minute, and I'm glad we did. He was great and the pricing was very reasonable and transparent. He even came to the Embarcadero with us after, which was great.

Went back to room 168 about 10 minutes before noon, got in line, got a ticket, hung out with our friends, and then we heard our number. We went in and met Virginia, who was to marry us. She was super cool. She clearly loves marrying people--she said she did it on a volunteer basis, twice a month.

So one thing with city hall marriages is that you don't really know where it'll happen in the building until "the moment of." It so happened that at noon today there was Irish dancing in the rotunda, so we couldn't go there.

What I learned, which would have been good to know before, was that if you can't use the rotunda, you can (usually? often?) go up to the fourth floor on one of the walkways overlooking the rotunda. We lucked out here and had another marriage ceremony right before us, and so while they were going first, my photographer scouted the two walk-ways and highly recommended the light in one of them being better (the less bright one, basically). So I asked if we could swing over to that one, and there we went.

BTW I was worried the day before because the website says only 6 people can be with you. including babies, photographers, and so on. And with our last minute photographer decision, we had 6 + 2 photographers. My guess now is that it's mostly an issue if you're in the small room, because it seems like generally, even if the rotunda is a no-go, you can use one of the 4th floor walkways. In that case, there's room for more than 6, yes? Anyhow there was no "headcount" and we were just fine on the numbers front.

For the ceremony itself, Virginia led us through simple but profound wedding vows, which she knew by heart. She was absolutely "present and connected" with us. It was a really special moment--I'd read good things about the "City Hall Marriage" experience on Yelp, but this was REALLY good. wow. Thank you San Francisco.

ps: we went for lunch at Chaya on the Embarcadero after, and that worked out really well. Good food and service, nice views of the water, reasonable valet parking. I tried to find something nice for lunch walking distance from city hall but it wasn't to be so Chaya was a good bet.
author: Paul K.

description: We just had our wedding here. Spend the money to rent this place out, Or, come during a time where there are not so many people. It was absolutely gorgeous. There is not one single area where it would be a bad picture area. The staff there were great on the day before. They helped us thru our paperwork, the lady processing our forms was very informative. Gave us envelopes for everything. Smiled, greeted us, just the works. This is why I love my home town.
author: Tony G.

description:
My now-wife and I just got married at City Hall two weeks ago, and it was an excellent experience.  A couple of points I should hit on for those considering it s a venue ...
1. Cost: this is a standout, it is CHEAP.  License and ceremony combined are under $300.  We figure, more $$$ for things like a honeymoon or a down payment, both of which last longer.
2. Ease: not too tough, though warn guests they'll have to go through metal detectors.  Just be sure to book your license and ceremony appointments as soon as you can in the given window (separate appointments, and they fill up).
