3. Privacy: not so much.  It is a public space after all, and if they're busy weddings can go assembly-line style.  We were fine with it, but make your own informed choices.
4. Ambiance: a mix of neoclassical and deco architecture.  Gorgeous.  The lighting is dark though (the peril of such a large space) so warn your photographer.
5. Parking and logistics: this can be a nuisance.  There is parking underground at Civic Center Plaza (entrance on McAllister, north side of the park).  But if you can, take public transit, a cab, Uber, Lyft, skateboard, what have you.  SF traffic stinks, 24/7/365, always has and always will (right up there with death and taxes).
6. Party size: the City Hall website will tell you it's 6 max, including a photographer.  However, within reason, this rule can be bent, as we had about 20 people.  It is a public space after all.  But be smart, and don't show up with a crowd that'd fill a Giants playoff game, as that will get you in hot water with the Sherriff's deputies faster than greased lightning.
All told we totally recommend it.  It was a great choice for us, and made our day wonderful.
PS one final item: stay in town the day before and day of.  No sense commuting somewhere same day ... a wedding is stressful enough!
author: Patrick C.

description: The city hall at SF is out of all proportion for a city of this size. It is a beautiful building with massive public spaces in a grand European design. The details in the dome and wall carvings are amazing. The tour on the other hand is a bit slow moving. The guide was personable and knowledgeable. Unfortunately the tour mainly consisted of walking into a room with some displays and then standing in a corner listening to some anecdotes then whizzing past the displays. The stories were interesting, but it would have been better to tie them into the displays or other visuals.  The council chamber was also impressive but the main dome was the highlight.
author: Ted B.

description:
YOU HAVE TO MAKE A RESERVATION TO APPLY FOR A MARRIAGE LICENSE. Somehow I missed this information on their website. I was disappointed after a 5 hour journey to get here. There was no parking anywhere. ALL lots were full. After maybe an hour, I finally got a spot. I knew you had to make an appt. for the ceremony, but I didn't realize you had to make an appt. just to apply for a marriage license. Sure, I thought it would be an hour or so wait. I pumped the meter full of change. A nickel bought me a minute. A dime bought me a few more. I think the machine said $3.00 an hour but I was pumping it full of change like mad and there was a 2 hour time limit on it, so that part was a little stressful.

The building inside is BEAUTIFUL. But the amenities definitely felt lack luster. The cafe area had a few tables but there were barely any chairs. Half of the room was empty. Where they could have set up another 10 - 15 tables, they didn't. It really felt as if they didn't want to encourage anybody staying. That's fine. It's City Hall. They have stuff going on. 

We got in line to apply for the marriage license and the lady asked "Do you have an appt.?". Uh oh. No we didn't. "Well, we're booked for today and the rest of the week" she said. UGH. Ok, so no sympathy for the out of towners. No "I'm sorry you drove all that way, but we really can't make exceptions". I would have liked to see some emotion. But it was more like DMV. "NEXT IN LINE PLEASE". 

I had already printed and filled out my marriage license form from online, gathered up birth certificates, passports etc. so I was prepared, but not prepared with an appt. I asked if it could be mailed in, and the answer was NO. This did however buy me more time to contemplate a name change. You have to decide what new middle and last name you'll be using as a married couple when you apply for the marriage license. No going back and making changes. 

So, my advice: Make a reservation online. And if they're this busy, I wonder if the ceremony service can be planned in the 90 day time frame they allow once the license is issued. Plan accordingly. And don't expect to find parking.
author: Lucy H.

description:
I could go on and on about how magnificent this building appears, especially when glimpsed from exiting from the BART station, but you just need to see it for yourself.

City Hall was fake "burned" during Roger Moore's "View to a Kill" bond.  SF was extremely cooperative with a bunch of stunts and shooting locales for the movie.
author: Stephen H.

description: I visited city hall for the first time last year, after seeing pictures of it, I was so excited. When I got there, it did not disappoint! It is absolutely the most beautiful building I think I've ever seen in California. The architecture is amazing, the detail takes your breath away. You could spend hours just looking at all the designs in the ceiling. It is free to walk into, but you are checked by metal detectors and your bags are also checked by guards. I didn't mind, and they were quite polite and very friendly to tourists. There's usually weddings there every day, I went on a Friday afternoon, and saw about 3-4 brides getting married. It truly is a magical experience.
author: Elena G.

description: It's supposed to open for public from 1--3pm, and we got here at 12:20, around 1pm, it was dozens of people from all over the world waiting outside to take a look of this great building inside, but two guys came out at 1:18 and telling us it's cancelled today... What a joke ! Shouldn't be posted like days or at least hours ahead instead of wasting people's time ?? Welcome today francisco
author: Kevin W.

description: Went to show dogs for lunch today parked 2 blocks up on Golden Gate almost din't eat after walking down the piss soaked streets in that area SF take some pride in your city and clean it up... Sorry Show Dogs we won't be coming back . Food was good but my wife said never again in that area.
author: Jeff W.

description: Came to look around and check out the city. The building is beautifully structured and it's no wonder people come here to look. I came mostly to check out the history for the place.
author: Corie L.

description:
No one's gonna read this review. So, I'll write about it in cat. 

Meow.. meow-meow-meow. 
Meeoow? Meow. 
Meow-meow, meow meow meow. purrrrrrrrrrrr.... 
Meow meow meow meow meow; meooooow!
Meoooow meow San Francisco, meow meooow.
author: Garland W.

description:
This is a review for a weekend wedding ceremony 2hr block.

Go figure that the venue is going to be a rather difficult place to work with because it is city own property. 

When looking at venues for our ceremony, we thought that this would be the perfect place for it. We placed a hold on it with a deposit and come time that we paid the remaining deposit, an additional 300 dollar restoration fee was added. There was no conversation about this in the beginning and we were actually surprised that it showed up. Obviously we wouldn't cancel the venue because everyone already knew that our wedding ceremony was going to be there.

FYI, this didn't really bother me but it was kind of expected. There are a lot of things that city hall does not allow. If things are not allowed on the contract and you don't see whether your specific detail of your wedding  is allowed, make sure you ask! 

Vendors- only vendors with liability insurance are allowed. This basically wipes out a good portion of vendors out there. Make sure you ask the vendors if they have insurance.

Lastly, the one thing that did annoy me the most was on the wedding day. We were standing in front of the main entrance of city hall waiting to get in.  We could even see people standing inside however a little past our designated time schedule, they didn't even bother to tell us that we (the wedding party) and ALL our guests need to enter at the side of the building where the loading dock was. I had elderly guests that they wanted to send around the corner to enter the building. We argued with them for that because my 80+ year old grandparents already spent so much time walking to the venue that we did not want them to walk around the building to get in. That ate into the time that we were scheduled for building use and they are strict with the 2 hr time block.

Otherwise, the three stars awarded was purely for the beauty of the building. I can't say that the operations of this building was exactly what I had in mind. More troublesome to work with. According to my wedding coordinator, they were a hit and miss with communication. There was a break in communication for myself since I was informed that my point of contact no longer worked there. I found out 2 weeks after no communication from city hall that she left employment there. 

City hall is just a beautiful building without decorations. That was the best part because we hardly needed any decorations for this place.

If you decide to select this place for your event, weigh out your options before committing. For me It was worth it because I wanted to get married here. For others, the hassle may not be worth it. p.s. Book early if you want the 1-3pm ceremony slot on Saturdays, those book out fast.
author: Kimmy C.

description:
Fond memories of this place from 5 years ago, when I married my husband.  

When you think of getting married at city hall, the words "glamorous" and "beautiful" are not words that would normally come to mind.  But this place has a ton of old-school charm.  After seeing all of the other happy brides/grooms dressed to the nines, it made me a little embarassed actually that I didn't wear something more formal for our special day.

Also, when we went to get copies of our marriage certificate a year ago they were fast and efficient... even the registrar's offices were well-kept and charming.

Three cheers for SF city hall.  I really hope they don't sell this gem, no matter how bad the economy gets.
author: Christina G.

description: As a landmark, this is a beautiful place to visit for tourists, and I've heard people also prefer this for weddings (cheaper venue yet still beautiful). For special events they'll light up the hall with beautiful colors (as you can see in the photos). I happened to pass by on the 75th Anniversary of the Golden Gate Bridge and it was all lit up in international orange. :)
author: Esther Y.

description:
I am not a wedding person. Not one tiny bit. I wanted to elope, but my SO (I guess he's my husband now, WEIRD) reaaaaaally wanted to have a ceremony, even a small one.  After considering a few different options, City Hall was going to be the cheapest -- and most beautiful.

For about $200, you too can get married in a spectacular historical building! You can reserve your date up to 90 days in advance, and I'd recommend getting your license and doing the ceremony on different days, to eliminate as much stress as possible.

You meet your judge right before the ceremony, which is a little strange, but it all went smoothly -- I felt obligated to make sure that she was not putting the words "obey" in the vows and wouldn't be referring to us as "man and wife."  She chuckled and assured me that no, neither of those things would happen.  (Bless her.)  The ceremony itself was less than 5 minutes. YAY!

The single drawback, at least to me, was that there were tons of tourists videotaping and photographing our ceremony! I suspect we are going to end up in someone's photo album back home...

Bottom line: I'm really happy with our choice to hold the ceremony here. Inexpensive, gorgeous, and as simple as humanly possible.
author: Jennie K.

description: My cousin took me here to sit on the steps to just talk.  I was surprised at the lack of noise that surrounded this building, even with all the tourists! Very pretty place to be.
author: Michelle N.

description:
On a  recent trip to SF, I went back to the City Hall. It was as beautiful as I remembered it from some years ago. Very elegant architecture.

I took the free tour and learned some interesting and of course quirky (as it is SF) history related to  City Hall.

I would strongly recommend a trip to City Hall and the free tour. 

And, be sure to see the Asian Art Museum it is just across the plaza. It is wonderful.
author: Elyn Z.

description:
Visually awesome!!!!
My BF's grandmother passed away and she was given a memorial here.
It was a perfect place for the occasion.
I was told that all kinds of celebrations like weddings are held here all the time.
In life there are times to laugh and there are times to cry- 
Anyways, her life was celebrated- she was an awesome person!!!!!

Everything was prepared and cleaned up in a timely fashion - staff was helpful.
With everthing going so smoothly it helped to make going through this occasion just a little bit more easier.....
author: Ursula U.

description:
CITY HALL
An excellent and beautiful place where you can get married quickly, and without fuss! Just find parking right outside, get to your appointment, sign some papers with a witness, and say your vows in a ceremony complete with an officiant under the rotunda... and just like that... you're married!!!
author: Stanley C.

description:
The Salesforce Holiday Party finally allowed me to get inside and see City Hall for myself.

I have walked and driven by SF's City Hall multiple times, and it has been on my to-do list to check out the inside for months now. And let me tell you I was NOT disappointed. It is GORGEOUS!! Granted it was very decorated and embellished for the party but even so, the architecture was breathtaking and the dome was really cool! There is also a really ornate looking grand staircase that leads up to the second floor where the mayor's office is, and it's really fun to walk up the stairs because you feel like royalty =)

Definitely a cool place to visit, and there are statues and cool displays in the side rooms as well that teach you about SF!
author: Sam F.

description: What a fab place to do a wedding! So beautifully breathtaking, so many spots for dramatic photos and just a happy vibe as others create memories. Wish I and my hubster had thought of this instead of the quickie Tahoe wedding, though we are still going strong after 16 amazing years (love ya hon), this really would have been a "wow" moment for a spur of the moment wedding. I would totally recommend this idea, to someone looking for a small, intimate locale by the bay with a night out on the town. What could be better than SF when it's right in your backyard!
author: Susan D.

description:
I just had my wedding here and the building is beautiful. 

The one star is for the Events Department in City Hall. I rented out the whole fourth floor for my big day which the events department is in-charge of and they dropped the ball big time. I was convinced that no other wedding parties would be allowed but as my wedding began so did a whole other party across the way which affected my wedding photos. My photographer had to shoot at odd angles so I didn't have the other party in my photos. Instead of the events department taking care of the situation, they did nothing about it. I had to have one of my guest go and make the events department do their job which was too late.  

Another issue I had with the events department is that I rented chairs as well which were not setup prior to my wedding. Events Department were suppose to setup chairs and block off with a sign stating it was reserved for my wedding. I had to have one of my guest take care of this as well. 

Events Department at SF City Hall has not responded to my emails or phone calls. I think the whole situation was unorganized and unacceptable. 

If you're a bride booking the fourth floor at SF City Hall I would advise against it.
author: Sabrina C.

description:
San Francisco City Hall is absolutely stunning...inside and out. 

It is located at one of my favorite spots in San Francisco...the Civic Center.  The Civic Center as a whole has been home to many events over the years but I can say that I attended an event that only happened once at City Hall...

A rave.

Yep...you heard me right.  One magical night many moons ago there was an actual rave held at City Hall.  It was like 9 or 10 years ago and it only happened once.  I remember going through metal detectors and having actual police officers search people belongings.  

To this day I have no idea how the whole night was pulled off.  Thousands of ravers dancing on the rotunda steps with a DJ at the very top of the room. The room on the side was a second room with different music if I remember right.  

Reading through the reviews of SF City Hall I did not realize that so many people got married here. I would have never thought about it...I loved my Vegas wedding but a wedding here would have been pretty awesome as well. 

City Hall was also an amazing backdrop for the end of the San Francisco Giants 2010 World Series Championship Parade.  It was amazing seeing a sea of orange and black at City Hall to celebrate the first ever baseball championship for the city.

No matter if you are a Giants Fan, want to get married or went to a rave, San Francisco City Hall seems to be a place where a whole lot of once in a lifetime things happen. 

Totally 5 stars.

:0)
author: Eric N.

description:
Stunning! The interior is absolutely gorgeous! I wouldn't mind getting married here although maybe not my wedding reception. I knew someone who held their wedding here and it is not good if you are going to have music. 

I had my prom here. I love the cool marble and the huge staircase. 

They are open to the public on weekdays. Got to go through a metal detector. You can also get your passport here and all the city officials work here. Maybe you'll see the major!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous!!!

It's free to enter, but be aware that you are to be screened by security and metal detectors upon entering.

I was really amazed on how beautiful SF's City Hall is. In fact, there were several civil services occurring back to back on the steps leading to the second floor. 

Make a quick pit-stop if you're in the area. It's worth a look-see just to see how your city hall compares to SF's.
author: Maria C.

description:
And I'm telling you Jennifer Holliday's not go-o-o-o-o-ing...

Ever since the rotunda had been refurbished several years ago, I never had an excuse to visit City Hall in all its glory until the 2007 Equality Awards event this past weekend. Now before you think I'm some high-falutin', hill-rollin' sugar daddy with deep pockets, I have to clarify I was just a lowly volunteer picking up completed donation cards at the banquet. In fact, I think people were expecting me to bus tables, but I don't touch food that doesn't go in my mouth. Know what I mean?

If you haven't seen it, the voluminous rotunda is really a beautiful Beaux-Arts masterwork with its grand staircase and beautiful columns. A lot of people were dressed to the nines that night, including most of the local political celebrities since it was a black-tie occasion. It was a no-show for Newsom for reasons unfortunately too clear this past week. The rotunda was given lots of colorful lighting, and there were tables filled with fancy-schmantzy silent auction items. And I couldn't keep myself away from all the little mini-desserts.

Now I do have a genuine interest in ensuring civil liberties for all of us, but truth be told, I was there because I knew Jennifer Holliday was performing after dinner. I saw her 25 years ago when she played Effie in "Dreamgirls" on Broadway, and the memory of her landmark performance still sends goose pimples down my spine. They set up the elevated base of the staircase as the stage and she came down all those steps to thunderous applause.

She dropped nearly 200 pounds since I saw her perform in 1982, and her voice was just as incredible as ever - a roof-raising roar that almost blew the top of the rotunda off. She generously sang five songs, but of course she had to sing HER song. Her introduction put her in pure diva mode..."They tried to steal my song away from me. I fought for Effie, and I fought for this song. And nobody's gonna take it from me 'cause...I'm tellin' you I'm not going..."

Those goose pimples came back in full force, and I was lucky enough to be standing about 15 feet away from her this time. But she didn't end with her signature song...she finished with a gospel-fueled cover of Celine Dion's "Love Can Move Mountains" complete with a line of chorus boys in black leotards flailing white satin sheets on the stairs. There were even two adagio-style dancers doing their dance club moves next to her...kinda like what Jack did next to Jennifer Lopez when she performed at Karen's wedding reception on "Will and Grace".

It was a great evening...in a great building. And to think I'm only a ten-minute walk away.
author: Ed U.

description:
Got married here on a Monday morning in October.  There was no one there!  Our photos looked like we had the place to ourselves (because we practically did).  Definitely recommend the early work week wedding - we went the Friday before to get our license and the place was a zoo. 

We got married on the landing of the grand staircase around 11:30am.  Our photographer said the lighting was excellent.  The ceremony was literally 2 minutes - saying "I do" and then exchanging the rings.  But it was short and sweet and got the job done!

My husband and I had talked about eloping somewhere, and when we saw this place we knew it would be perfect...and it was.  Definitely recommended for anyone looking for a beautiful, affordable location to have a simple ceremony.
author: Molly S.

description:
Tips for those who wish for a simple wedding ceremony. http://www.sfgov2.org/index.aspx?page=96#_MARRIAGE_LICENSES_&

We got married on a Thursday afternoon here. Booked marriage license appointment ($99+ $5 convenience fee) and ceremony ($75 + $5 convenience fee) three months ahead online. Filled out marriage license form the day before. 

On the day of,  we checked in at the County Clerk's for the marriage license, hung out at the cafe for a bit (just FYI, the City Hall restroom is not the best place to get dolled up), and met up with friends for the ceremony an hour later. Since it was midweek, City Hall was nearly empty. We got to marry at a location of our choosing. In our case, we liked the lighting on the fourth floor and it was away from spectators.  We told our officiant that we didn't want to exchange rings so it cut our ceremony down to less than five minutes. Although the website said you shouldn't have more than 6 people present for the ceremony,  the couple before us had about a dozen guests. I suppose the rules are lax for non-busy weekdays.  

Officiant will turn in the paperwork for you if you have the ceremony here. You wait ten days and send in request for marriage certificate ($14 a copy. http://www.sfassessor.org/index.aspx?page=33#HCIGACOMMC). Don't bother using VitalChek for online ordering! It seems more complex than mailing the request yourself and a notary is still required for the authorization form (to be faxed in to SF County Assessor-Recorder). I've been waiting for five days and counting for VitalChek to confirm fax receipt. I had to call the Recorder directly to confirm. VitalChek website says ordering takes 20-30 days. I will go with 30 days at the rate this is going.  

As for how beautiful the City Hall is for photos, what everyone else said. You won't regret it.
author: Tif W.

description:
We got married there on March 23, 2007.  There were no protests
scheduled or weird holiday scheduled either.  The newly remodeled rotunda is amazing.  I loved it because while we were giving our vows there were field trips of children all around and got to watch us get married.  So my husband and I will be in the memories of countless children and their idea of getting married at city hall.  My profile photo was taken at the bottom of the stairs in the rotunda.  We couldnt have chosen a better place to get married or a better day.  

Just a quick history lesson, Marilyn Monroe and Joe Dimaggio got married there and that is why  I chose SF City Hall.  We kept it small like they did and it was perfect.  

I cant look at a photo of the building without getting all gitty inside.  Thats why I love all the coverage of all the gay marriages that have been happening there.  I get to see the same place I stood on the news almost every night.

You couldnt ask for a better place to be married.
author: Ivy R.

description: San Francisco really knows how to take care of the homeless and mental ill. This is very evident with the amount of nasty people ready to scare you here.
author: Fernando Y.

description: Where can I start the building itself is beautiful inside and out I am currently finishing up my internship and I will miss this wonderful place it is remarkably pretty and breath taking inside and out!
author: Yvette S.

description:
My husband and I eloped here in May and couldn't be happier with the way we got married. Okay, so I don't really have much to say about all the happenings in City Hall other than I got to book our appointment online to get our license and have our ceremony and even though the website stressed being on time, when we were 15 minutes late, no one made a big deal about it. We got married in the rotunda by Cynthia Gregory and it was beautiful. A little while later we made a trip back to City Hall to spend the day in the city and get our marriage license and again, no long lines or hassles, we got it really quickly.

We brought a photographer along to photograph our ceremony as well as our huge adventure visiting all our family members in the area afterwards to tell them we got married. 

Heads up to any future elopers - this is a gorgeous location, an absolute beautiful place to say your vows to your spouse. There's an underground parking lot which is right in front of City Hall so make sure to park there. Also, go early in the morning if you can so if you want to take pictures around City Hall, there are fewer people in the background.
author: Caroline I.

description: Local politician catering to street bums, round them up and clean up your city for crying out loud.
author: Tony S.

description: Great place to walk around. There are a few folks taking their wedding pictures here as well. Place is amazingly huge! Great picture-op anywhere!
author: Jeff A.

description: San Francisco's City Hall is beautiful inside!  I have seen a number of wedding ceremonies held here, and what a lovely place to have it.  The architecture is just gorgeous and will make you go ooo awww, lovely.  I go here to pay my property taxes, and while I am there, I always make it a point to walk around and enjoy it there too.  It is especially festive at Christmas time with the beautiful Christmas tree and decorations.  I've also been there for events like dance performances and seeing Tony Bennett sing his famous "I Left my Heart in San Francisco".  I know that they also have Zumba classes available here and there are food trucks at lunchtime on Fridays.  What a great well-rounded place - love it!  I know no other city hall like it!
author: Maile N.

description: Tonight while walking back to the hotel from dinner near Civic Center we exclaimed "oh my" to a homeless woman pooping as discretely as possible in a corner. She apologized. I think this great city needs to apologize to its homeless for not providing a place to relieve themselves and feel somewhat human. Shame on you San Francisco!
author: Eric M.

description:
I had no idea:
1. that it was so beautiful inside
2. that at any given moment, swarms of tourists would come flooding in
3. that this was even a tourist destination

I thought I saw what looked like someone arriving to take her quinceanera pictures inside but it turned out to be the bride arriving to get her wedding pics. 

The security process was speedy, the staff getting us through were incredibly friendly and perhaps probably the most pleasant security folks I've ever met. I hope they're paid well. 

We rode the elevator and found that charming too. 

It's easy to find, the dome is quite pretty, and the exterior gets lit up with colors on special occasions. Basically, with the exception of non-exciting lighting in some interior offices, I can't think of any reason not really like it here.
author: Loli L.

description:
I did not get married here, but I did get my license here. Let me just say that the building alone is a tourist attraction in itself. Dare I say it rivals the Capital of Texas? Well, almost. 

I also want to note how nice the people inside were, and I just did not expect anyone to be nice at all. In Houston at least, most city/ government workers aren't. Postal Service? Forget it. 

Still, I'm sure part of why they were nice is because we had done our homework. So, just to let you know, if you do need to visit to get your license, you are required to pay and make an appointment online before coming. Read the information and make sure you bring all the appropriate documents. If you have any questions, call ahead. I'm sure they will appreciate it, and your visit will be a pleasant one. 

The Verdict: I say even if you don't need anything here, you should take a walk inside. It is a lovely place.
author: Cara S.

description:
Incredibly beautiful... the light seems to shine and fall perfectly in this rotunda. Hard to not get good pictures. Everything is just perfect here. 

Went here for a wedding and they followed a really strict schedule. I don't blame them... I can see lots of people wanting to get married here! When they said 12:20 start.. it was really a 12:20 start. The rotunda area is specifically closed off for the duration your event is going on. They also do bag check and security checks before you enter. 

What's cool is that you can have food and drinks inside...very impressed. 

I bet it must be expensive to rent out this area just for a private event!
author: Mimi C.

description:
Wow! 
Such a beautiful place to get married! My husband and I got married here last year just us and our witnesses. It was truly amazing. We had our big wedding celebration a few months ago that was also spectacular but I will always be thankful I have the sweet memories from our intimate ceremony at the beautiful SF City Hall! 

If you need a great photographer check out www.ashleypaige.photoshelter.com
author: ashley r.

description: If you are considering getting married here do it!!  The building  is stunning and ceremony will be short and  sweet.  We wrote our own vows and didn't get to say them as the justice seemed to have his own set already but you might be able to if you tell them ahead of time when you meet in the office?  We definitely exceeded the 4 person limit for the ceremony with about 20 but aside from a disapproving look from the court justice marrying us we carried on.   If you have a specific date in mind make sure you get online exactly 90 days in advance (thats as early as you can make it) especially if you want a Friday afternoon (as we did) .   There were lots of other couples inside getting married as well as people stopping in to see the building but that was all part  of the excitement.   Definitely hire a photographer ( check out Jamie at Studio 13 designs) to capture the magic.
author: Robin D.

description:
Really beautiful building, inside and out. I didn't realize how many people actually got married there, but now I can understand why. 
Aside from the kind of rundown atmosphere that you get from the surroundings outside; this would be a great place to spend to spend a day exploring and learning about the history.
author: Mike P.

description:
Strangely going to see City hall was one of the things that I wanted to do while I was in San Francisco. So I walked there and was surpirsed to find several food trucks outside. Even before I get inside this place is already awesome. I walk in and it just so happens that I am 10 minutes there before the next free tour, sign up? Heck yeah.

While waiting the 10 minutes I saw about 10 couples whom either just got married were getting married or were waiting. All of them beautiful. I didn't know any of the girls but all were so gorgeoous and happy that I wanted to go up to all of them and congratulate them. They were all taking wedding photos inside cause it is just that gorgeous. So gorgeous that I think I found the location for my wedding. I am not the kinda girl that gets super excited about weddings but this place sparks something inside of me.  

The inside is just gorgeous!!!!! The tour was free and I learned actually a lot. It will probably be a little dry for those who are not into history or arcituecture. It was very intresting about how they have pretty much earthquake proofed the place. Also the dome is taller than the nations capital. OMG!!!

I love this place I took about a million photos every one of them is gorgeous.
author: Cris F.

description:
If you're thinking about holding an event here - remember - it's a public building and your guests have to go through security to get in - which kinda puts a damper on the celebration when everyone has to wait in line - like you're at the airport.

Yes - it's a beautiful facility but make sure you have the right caterers who can keep the pace between two floors (reception and sit-down dinner) and the food hot on arrival and not having sat in trucks and ovens so by the time you sit down, the salad has been sitting at your table for at least four hours and your "hot" food is not so hot and a bit wilty...and even when you had a choice of entree you end up getting what you didn't want so what was the point of asking.

The idea of City Hall as a reception/sit-down event is great - but you better be sure the catering company you hire has it together...cuz no matter what happens, they're making their money and you should get your money's worth. City Hall - thumbs up; catering company- thumbs down; security-annoying.
author: Dee Z.

description: I've lived here for 6 years, but somehow never made it in here until last week, when I had to come in twice. The building itself is gorgeous; had no idea this hidden gem was even here. Both times I came in, there were a slew of weddings going on, which gives the place a cool vibe (happy newlyweds are more fun than the somber government workers I expected to encounter). Both the departments I had to deal with were super helpful, with none of the lines I was expecting.
author: Pat M.

description:
This remains one of the best buildings in San Francisco - inside and out!

Too bad all the new construction around Market and toward downtown doesn't hold a candle to this crown jewel.
author: Alex S.

description:
Incredible, timeless architecture. City Hall is one of my favorite places that hosts big bougie events. I attended the Black and White ball and was able to get all dapper dan up in this place - black suit and bow-tie. A large mezzanine equipped with multiple bars and servers lead down a huge stairwell into the main ballroom area. 

The acoustic of this place were also remarkable. Best part about it? My good friend proposed to his long time girlfriend during the dinner - booyah!
author: Jason M.

description: For the love of god, please don't have your wedding or event  here. The people that run this place are extremely rude and unprofessional. I've been to a million weddings in my lifetime and this place is horrible. They have horrible sheriffs as their mall cops that are very rude. You're better off having an event at IHOP than trying to build memories there. Take my word for it!
author: Burke N.

description:
I got married here last week and it was fantastic. 

The instructions on the website were very clear, and prepared us well for our license and ceremony appointments. We booked our appointments online with ease about a week in advance, and plenty of appointments were available. On the "big day", we both used passports as ID and didn't need any other paperwork. Our license appointment was all finished in just 15 minutes, and we went off to get ready for our ceremony. We left a 2 hour gap between our appointments, and I was glad to have that time to do my makeup and change clothes. 

The ceremony was wonderful. Those with negative stereotypes/preconceptions about city hall weddings should definitely leave them at the door! Our officiant, Valerie Walker, was so kind. The introduction and vows she gave were very beautiful, and she seemed so warm and so genuinely happy for us. We had one witness, a good friend who also took pictures for us. A *lot* of tourists took pictures of us from the edge of the rotunda, but they didn't bother us at all -- the ceremony still felt wonderfully intimate and happy, and they all clapped for us when we kissed, which was sweet. The ceremony lasted only about ten minutes, but was very meaningful and memorable.
author: Kathleen H.

description:
Venue: Very grand. My partner interns here, and I'm jealous he gets to walk up those pretentious steps everyday. Red carpet included (sometimes) 

Amenities: There's a cafe inside. No wifi. You can get married here, and I'd argue it's probably one of the better looking city halls in the bay area to get married in! haha

Accessibility: BART ride away. Get off at Civic Center.

Nearby: Asian Art Museum, Bill Graham Civic Auditorium, SF Opera House, Little Saigon, UN Plaza

Tip: Security checks included. 

Will I come back? If I had any business in city hall again. lol
author: Emmanuel C.

description: Beautiful building!  A true treasure of SF.  And they were very helpful when I went to get my birth certificate.  Who knew they kept pieces of SF history, like my birth, for that long?
author: Rebecca H.

description: This is addresed to the mayor Your city is a very nasty city filled with blacks, the streets are dirty some of the cops are dirty and having the Company Kink here make this city look very crappy the only good part in San Francisco is Fishermans wharf if you took out Kink and cleaned up the city this would be a 5 star city.
author: David R.

description:
Gorgeous exterior aside, I had a great experience going to City Hall to fix a voter registration issue. After the security screening (which admittedly does make you feel a bit like you're heading into an airport or jail), the folks who helped me out at the Department of Elections were quick, kind, gracious, and most importantly, effective. 

Good work, SF.
author: Allison S.

description:
I will get married here.

Coming from the mid west when i tell people i want to get married in SF city hall they cringe.  I know what they are invisioning... a run down state office building with a musty smell.  

Not in SF.  After seeing pictures they agree.  I will be getting married here.
author: Lauren T.

description:
I got an email from my sister asking if I wanted to go to a wedding of her dear friends at SF City Hall on October 17, 2009. I checked my calender and I was actually in town, and said yes. I thought, well, this will be one of those 5-minute-after-getting-the-license-at-City-Hall type weddings. Not sure why I was invited. 

Woo hooo, was I Wrong! 

This wedding was like no other wedding I have ever attended and like not other I probably ever will attend again. It was a once in a lifetime experience for all 100+ guests.  They weren't just getting married at City Hall, they were renting out City Hall for 6 hours!

It was a black and white affair, with friends and family flying in from Berlin, Munich, Greece, L.A., New York, MIami, Hawaii plus the local friends from Atherton, Carmel, and the Nob HIll neighbors! 

We entered city hall and were welcomed by a quartet of trumpeteers playing several fanfares of majestic revery as we were handed champagne flutes. 

Then we were invited to enter the gorgeous Rotunda under the gold gilded dome, a cavernous, breathtaking sight with its huge marble center staircase. White orchids were everywhere. The Starlight Strings octet played beautiful songs like "Some Enchanted Evening". 

Panis Anglicus - a beautiful aria was sung by Leslie in an enchanting soprano operatic voice. 

Biset's Habanera from the Opera Carmen played as our beautiful bride, Suzanne, in her stunning red formal chiffon gown and her dashing groom, Dimitri, in his black tuxedo, descended the main stairs, moving past a double helix ring statue especially made for them. 

Nella Fantasia was read by Tina and sung like a nightingale by Leslie.

Pablo Neruda's "And Now You're Mine" was read with heartfelt warmth by Susan and Jorg. 

The service was delivered with such grace by Hank. 

And the bride and groom, well into middle age, were glowing and bubbling with love for each other at every moment, every turn. WIth warm glances, gentle laughter, near tearing at their vows. They tried to smooch 3 times before they were supposed to seal the deal!

It was beautiful!

And after this enchanting ceremony, the party started in the same rotunda after a receiving line in the landing above the marble stairs and a mixing of more refreshments and fabulous finger food as the tables were being set below.

As we were seated, Candace, who flew in from Kahala, Hawaii, sang the always lovely Hawaiian Wedding Song in Hawaiian. So beautiful. I love that song.  

And as the meal was served, HIlary Cole, who flew in from NYC's Birdland, sang several jazz tunes inspired by love. She was the only professional singer of the 3, and she was gorgeous and had a smooth voice and charming personality. She is big in Japan, too. 

A great heartfelt speech by son-in-law David, and plenty of good food and drink catered by the excellent Melons catering.

Later the disco came out and a nice mix of songs got the now "feeling happy" guests cutting the marble and lifting their spirits with pleasure.

The night went on until 11pm, and everyone had a unique, once in a lifetime, joyous and memorable experience. This was mostly made not by the opulence of the ceremony, but by the warm, sincere grace of the charming couple who genuinely made everyone attending, guests and help, feel close to them as they shared the happiest day of their lives with family and friends.

I knew the bride, but it is my sister who has known her for 2 decades and has been her Muse of Muses. I was my sister's date but felt honored to be there and see the love radiate out from this happy couple.  

Despite everything appearing overwhelming well planned and executed, I did hear about some of the minor issues, since my sister was asked to assist in the production. But none of the minor flaps would ever detract from this fantastic wedding, made all the more special by the beautiful venue that is San Francisco's City Hall Rotunda. 

Trust me, this was not the normal SF City Hall wedding after getting the license ceremony.
author: Wanugee N.

description:
what a great place for a wedding.  I think we were about 200 people and fit nicely.
You do need mikes to be able to hear since all the marble makes the sounds bounce and travel.  The bride gets to come down the marble stairs.  Very romantic.
author: Eddie M.

description: Beautiful place inside and out with so many picture perfect spots if you're planning on getting married here.  Came here for our licensing and you are required to make an appointment online first before heading down here.  Everything was done in a timely manner however if you're wanting a ceremony done it could take up to two hours waiting around so just be sure to keep yourself occupied with interesting and fun company.  Love all the pillars and the stairway to the ceremony spot.
author: Sharon N.

description:
My hubby and I recently had our dream wedding at San Francisco City Hall.  When I say dream wedding, I truly mean it. For 1 day, I felt like a real princess.  Our wedding was PERFECT, and it wasn't over the top with florals or extensive decor. Why? Simply because SF City Hall doesn't need it.

We rented out SF City Hall for Saturday, 09.10.11.  Due to the 'specialty' date, as referred to by many of our vendors, we rented it out far in advance. I suggest you do the same if you decide to host your wedding here.  You can place a 'hold' without a deposit and if anyone else wants to book your date, City Hall will call you and give you the option of submitting a deposit or letting go of the hold. (FYI - the deposit is 75% of total rental fee and must be paid in Cash or Check)

We explored many different beautiful options like the Asian Art Museum, Ritz Carlton, Bently Reserve, Cavallo Point, The Fairmont, Four Seasons, StoneTree Golf Club, Flood Mansion, Omni Hotel, Sir Francis Drake Hotel, Julia Morgan Ballroom, de Young Museum, etc. 

The moment we walked into SF City Hall both of our jaws dropped and we knew it was the place for us.  We were immediately wowed by the marble floors, intricate details in architecture, and the grand stairway of the rotunda.  I instantly pictured our wedding ceremony, seating, tables for our reception, and all the beautiful Tiffany Blue accents our day would bring.

Our wedding started at 5:30pm sharp with a 30-minute ceremony at the rotunda.  After the ceremony, guests were escorted to the Mayor's Balcony for cocktails and hors d'oeuvres.  During the cocktail reception, our caterer and wedding coordinator teamed up to change the ceremony decor to dinner tables.  Everything happened quickly and smoothly.  Around 7:15 guests were directed to the elevators and they made their way back down to the rotunda for dinner and dancing.  Our sweetheart table was placed on the platform of the grand staircase.  We had an amazing view of all tables and all of our guests had a clear view of us.  I hate it when I go to weddings and I can't see what's happening due to the poor layout of the venue.  This was certainly not the case at SF City Hall.  Plus, the beautiful interior made a spectacular backdrop for photos.

We had a photo booth near the South Light Court.  It was a great location to keep away from the aesthetics of the wedding celebration but easy for guests to stumble to after several cocktails.  Our all-night Open Bar was a big hit! =P

I will warn you that City Hall is extremely uptight with events.  At our initial meeting, prior to putting down a deposit, we were told that they're more laid back than other venues. (ie. Asian Art Museum - even more strict than SF City Hall)  SF City Hall was not laid back at all and several issues came up as we got closer to the wedding date.  I completely understand because it is a government building.  They have to abide by different regulations than a typical hotel or restaurant but it would have been nice to hear all of this from the get go rather than a surprise with only a couple weeks to go.  They require an ALL VENDORS site visit where they'll basically tell everyone the do's and don'ts of the venue.  They also have to PRE-APPROVE several factors of your event.  We received many preliminary approvals but had to go through it again 2 weeks prior to the wedding. In our case it was Unity Candles (used during the ceremony), kneeling bench (used during the ceremony), photo booth placement, loose diamond decor on tables, votives, and a few other things.  It surprised me that they were really strict w/our wedding only because they've allowed New Year's Eve parties and raves.  How could our small wedding even compare to the madness of these events?  

SF City Hall requires that SF Police and the Fire Marshall are present the entire time so that's another big expense, on top of the rental fee.  Insurance is also required and you can purchase through City Hall but if you do your research like we did, you can save some $.  We obtained the same insurance for 1/3 of what they charged.

Our wedding concluded at midnight.  It was beyond beautiful and our guests had a fabulous time.  Many of them said it was the best wedding they had ever been to and I agree, though I am biased. ;)  

If you're tight on $$$, SF City Hall also has an affordable wedding package for only $4,000 for a 2-hour rental.
author: Nikki C.

description:
Great experience both times coming here. 

Had to get a copy of a birth certificate from vital records and for passport processing at the Tax Collector. Both departments I went to had knowledgeable employees and processing was highly efficient.

Would definitely come back if I needed to.
author: Jen F.

description:
4.5 stars.

As a wedding venue in San Francisco, maybe even most of the United States, nothing beats City Hall. We checked out a bunch of different elegant places in SF, Julia Morgan Ballroom, The Green Room, The Bentley Reserve and a few other places but as soon as my wife, then fiancee at the time, saw City Hall, we knew it was the place.

A lot of our guests were posting pictures on Facebook during the ceremony while we were standing on the steps and people were stunned by the venue and curious where the wedding was held. If you've never been you need to check it out. The architecture, columns, marble floors and details are out of this world and amazing.

The only reason I gave it a half star deduction is because it is a pricey place to rent, close to $15K in our situation and there is a lot of required paperwork, but it was well worth it. 

All of our guest said it was the most beautiful, elegant wedding they have ever attended. Check out our wedding video and you will see how beautiful this venue can be.

http://vimeo.com/41986990

What's nice about City Hall is it can somehow hold 300 - 500 people and yet still feel intimate. If you can afford it, nothing tops City Hall for your wedding venue. Evey penny was worth it. And Elsie and the rest of the events staff are very helpful.

Choosing City Hall was one of the best decisions we made regarding our dream SF wedding.
author: Binh D.

description: Gorgeous architectural building inside. My mommy & daddy got married here. Came here after my college graduation to take pictures cause it's nearby.
author: Amy C.

description:
Which BART station do you get off at to go to City Hall?

Are you retarded? Civic center !?

I would recommend going on a weekday while people are at work at take the tour. The building is stunning and has such a rich history. 

If you've got money to burn I would recommend this place to throw a party or wedding since apparently you can rent it for like 10k a night.

I always see couples getting married here. If you're going to choose any city hall in California to get married in, this is probably the one to do it in. Sorry, Fresno.
author: Carlos A.

description:
This is a rather amazing location. A friend told me I NEEDED to stop by here at least once to check out the City Hall. Now I had been in City Hall's before. Mostly in smaller towns. Plus I had fond memories of the Cook County Accessor's Office from the Blues Brothers. So I was not expecting much.

Holy crap this place is pretty! If I ever get married again I might even consider doing it here because there is so much character and history in this place. Someone was actually getting marries when I was wandering around and I did stop to watch for a few minutes.

Honestly I am rather amazed at the number of times I have walked by here and not realized what a visual piece of eye candy I was missing!
author: Nick B.

description:
It really is beautiful inside.  I had no idea how many weddings they do here a day.  It was interesting to see all the different outfits people wore for their ceremonies, and no one seemed put off that it was essentially a mill of wedding ceremonies.  I just saw a lot of smiles and tears of joy, hopefully.

The county clerk's office was easy to deal with and we were in and out in no time.
author: Seong P.

description: The dome! Known to most as the City Hall, is one of the most exquisite buildings in San Francisco. Breathtaking and beautiful at night. Occasionally there are events on the front lawn (e.g., Big communal screens set up for watching the World Cup).
author: Amy M.

description:
Absolutely stunning building....when my now husband and I decided to marry in the US, we elected California as the general place, finally choosing San Francisco as our ultimate destination.  We knew we'd be having a civil ceremony, and it would definitely be happening in a city hall as we didn't want to fuss about with arrangements and things, especially with us living an ocean apart at the time.

We had NO idea just how brilliant SF's City Hall was.  I guess we were both picturing our wedding happening in one of those generic concrete City Halls that are the norm in the US.  Imagine our surprise when I was looking for marriage license info and saw the photos of the glorious City Hall building!  I just couldn't believe it...it was like a beautiful, European Beaux-Arts building but in San Francisco, and used as their City Hall, of all things!  We were both over the moon.

We married in the main hall, under the grand rotunda.  Our officiant was lovely...TJ, I believe was how he introduced himself to us.  Very nice guy, and seemed to really enjoy his job.  In fact, everyone working at the City Hall when we were there seemed quite lovely and willing to help people with anything from baffling paperwork to walking directions to the museum.

I'd advise taking care of your license details in advance of the day, so that you can show up and just do the ceremony without fussing about.  Appointments are available for this part of the process. That said, it's not a difficult or lengthy ordeal--just a matter of filling out a rather short form and showing identification, and then paying the fees for the license and the ceremony itself.  We did this the day before our wedding, and then spent the next hour or so wandering around City Hall admiring everything.

It's probably also wise to reserve the date/time for your ceremony in advance, though again, not entirely necessary unless you have your heart set on a specific date/time, or you're traveling and can't wait around for an open ceremony time.  I believe the earliest you can book is 3 months in advance of the date you want.
author: Tuesday F.

description: WOW... AMAZING!  Many ppls thought it was DC but nope its SF!
author: Thai C.

description: I just got married at city hall think past September and it was a busy day!  The wait for the license, then the wait to be called, and then another wait for the ceremony were all expected but seemed extra long with the excitement and anticipation.  The building is still beautiful with its intricate and detailed architecture.  Photos of the building always turn out beautiful.
author: judy l.

description: Wondering if the Office of the State Labor Commisioner can be any more rude? Constantly talking over me, not waiting for me to finish my sentence/question, speaking down to us consistently, and giving me phone numbers and departments that couldnt help at all. You guys are doing a fantastic job - of not helping anyone and being the exact opposite of public service. There should be a way for you to measure how bad they are. I would challenge you to find a way to be any worse than you already are.
author: Molitoni F.

description:
You can't miss it - it's this spectacular, sparkling dome-shape building at the heart of San Francisco. Most tourists just walk around it and stroll on the UN Plaza outside the City Hall - which is fine - but I would recommend that if you can spare one hour of your time, go for the free guided walking tour which runs every weekday at 10:00am, 12 noon and 2:00pm, and explore the architectural wonders inside the building (information is on their website). For those of you coming from the East Coast or hail from the great continent of Europe, of course this is nothing compared to your great cathedrals and all that magnificent historical buildings from where you come from, but, well, we're at the West Coast here, and this IS something of value to us... 

If you have seen the movie "Milk," detailing the struggle of the gay activist Harvey Milk, well, this is THE place where he made that great speech to the supporting crowd. After he was shot, this is also the place where people spontaneously gathered, moving from Castro to this spot in a candlelight vigil, leaving flowers on the steps of City Hall. 

This place also has special significance for us. When we moved to San Francisco, we stayed in this quaint B & B called Hayes Valley Inn which is just a few streets from the City Hall. We can't walk anywhere without seeing this gorgeous, sparkling dome-shaped building! It sort of represent San Francisco to us, in a way.

So why 3 stars only? Well, the mayor, the bureaucrats, the politicians left and right, please take note of the homelessness, poverty and ugliness of cityscape that plague this Tenderlion-Civic Center area. Please. San Francisco is a GREAT city and please don't let it rot like that...
author: Rachel W.

description: Free tours at 1000, 1200 & 1400. You can also go in and just wander around up to 8pm (technically). We went one day after dinner and weren't let in to just wander. When we returned for the 1000 tour there were lots of people wandering around not on the specific tour. The tour though is worth it if you can make 1 of those 3 times. On the tour you get into rooms you can't access on tour own. The guide was so full of knowledge and so willing and eager to share stories. The 45-minute tour lasted about 80 minutes and was so informative on the building, architecture, symbolism, history of the city, etc... I recommend arriving early (or staying after) to walk around the 4th floor. It's the judicial center and not on the tour, but the guide said you can go up and walk anywhere the door is open. It's been designed to resemble its 1916 state, though is currently not the judicial branch's location (they outgrew it and moved to a new building).
author: Ben S.

description:
PASSPORT RENEWAL

1. Do research online to find out how to make an appointment, hours of operations, required forms, acceptable forms of payment.
2. Make an appointment 3-4 weeks in advance.
3. Print out required forms to fill out. DO NOT PRINT ON BOTH SIDES.
4. Take passport pictures at Walgreens.
5. Pack the filled form, old passport (if applicable), birth certificate/naturalization certificate, driver license, and a check book.
6. Arrive 10 mins before your appointment.
7. There is no check in, just proceed through the Treasurer & Tax department (Room 140) towards the back left and look for signs that say "PASSPORT"
8. Wait in waiting area to be called.
9. Turn in your pre filled form, old passport, passport pictures. Show your CA ID and birth certificate (I didn't have mine and I was ok. Had to forfeit my old passport though).
10. Write a check for $170 (express) and for $25 (processing fee).
11. Pay the $25 check fee to the cashier outside and come back in with receipt.

I was in and out within 20-30 minutes. SUPER EASY PROCESS!
author: Lisa N.

description: Such a beautiful architecture. I'm proud to say that we have such an elegant City Hall and the 5th highest dome in the world! Took a tour here with the fiancé since we both have never been and heavily considering getting married here. Learned a lot from the tour and gained an understanding about why they spent so much money on the renovation. The tour takes about an hour and the times it runs are: 10am, 12pm and 2pm (Mon-Fri). Lots of people getting married or taking engagement photos so you want to be mindful of that. I was just blown away with how pretty it is inside. Got to come down the grand staircase during the tour which was my favorite part. I can totally picture us having our ceremony here. Hopefully the next time I come back here would be for our big day! The Civic Center Parking Garage located across the street is very affordable but it's also a walking distance from the Civic Center Bart Station if you prefer to take public transportation.
author: Candice J.

description: What can I say? This place is beautiful! The design inside, the beautiful stairs we did our ceremony at and the staff that helped us was nice and friendly. Best part is.... its in SAN FRANCISCO!!
author: cherry w.

description:
Classy for our city.

I thought it fitting that my 900th review would be about  City Hall.  Not to mention, my viewing of Gavin handing out his usual perfect smiles and inducing speech with matching fluid hands and perfectly slicked back hair.  Sigh.  What can I say, he's good looking and extremely charismatic.  And he looks even better delivering all of this from the grand staircase; image consultants contracted to him, doing a good job.

A fantastic venue thanks to the neoclassical columns with an interior stabilized with massive granite and marble finishes.  No chintz here since I personally think anything gilded fake gold is cheesy but marble usually equates to a bit of class.  This definitely adds a bit of renaissance (and reminds me of the cherry wood tables with marble tops that my mum had all over the house, blah) and the stairs makes for a grand entrance to any speech, event, setup, foundation for the presenters.  The added skylights let in enough light during the day for a soft finish to any picture.  

Further information found here: http://www.sfgov.org/site/cityhall_index.asp?id=4354.  Wonder why the buildings situated around City Hall seem to flow with one another in terms of architectural parallels?  Excerpt from the site state "The architect was Arthur Brown Jr., who also designed San Francisco's Opera House, Veterans Building, Temple Emanuel, Coit Tower and 50 United Nations Plaza."  Hence no breaks to the visual eye.

I've been here for several venues and each time, they were methodically planned and the spaces efficiently utilized for maximum exposure.  It has a large capacity and the layout makes for easy mingling, although the hard rock surfaces carry laughter to the other side and heels echo continuously throughout the halls.  

Hands down, a lovely building during the day and even more so at night with the lights radiating the dome. Take a seat across the street and let the perfectly lined trees channel your view for a perspective.   

A true SF landmark.
author: Miika M.

description:
"Malou, get ready I'll pick you up in 15 mins, we're going to the City Hall" 

For a minute, I thought, "wow, that was the most quickest proposal anyone could get"...I burst into laughter and said "Arent you suppose to give me an ice first?"..."No silly, we will get your SF Resident Golf Card"....lol. 

So he was by my doorstep and off to the City Hall we went, I could have sworn there were several weddings that day.

So he showed me the way...to the window, well we got checked by Security first, the lady was so nice since Im carrying a large Jamba Juice...while I empty my pockets. Cholo said "Right this way"...

The guy in the window was very pleasant and patient, since we were giggling the whole time, as it turned out Cholo and him went to the same high school since they recognize each other. 

I took the picture and 5 mins later, Voila I have the Gold Card Yay!. He goes, "lemme see"...I think he is more excited than me.

I have been to several government offices and I must say this is the most efficient, pleasant and effective office I have seen and been in, in years.

Now, Im ready to play at Harding, Golden Gate, Lincoln with a discount.

Thanks Cholo.
author: Malou C.

description: We couldn't have picked a more epic and gorgeous location to get married! We rented out part of the 4th floor for about $1000- it was intimate and on a Tuesday at 11am we basically had the place to ourselves except for that bus-load of asian tourists that swarmed us with their cameras like the paparazzi as we stood on the grand staircase to take some photos... but hey, it was fun! ;oD  Would recommend this place to EVERYONE!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
San Francisco City Hall is a magnificent architectural treasure!

Yesterday, on Friday 19 May 2010, my son and I were playing local tourist.  I have lived in the bay area for over 30 years, and this was the first time I went inside the building.  I have been missing a treasure all these years.  This building ranks among the greatest works of civic architecture I have ever seen.  

The interior is dominated by the rotunda that reaches up to the giant dome.  According to the statistics I saw, is one of the tallest in the world and is taller than the dome over the US Capitol building in Washington DC.   There is a grand staircase from the first to second floor. This staircase was the scene of several weddings that were happening one after the other (it is a grand setting for a wedding!).  There is marble everywhere and grand carved plaster decorations on the archways and inner dome.  The second, third, and forth floors are open to the rotunda, giving many different viewing angles to appreciate all the architectural features as you explore the building. 

The dome is of interesting construction.  The outer dome is what is seen from the outside of the building.  The inner dome is in two parts, a lower part that has a large center opening, and an outer dome that surrounds the lower part and covers it.  Light filters from windows behind the lower part up and over it, reflecting on the upper part, giving an indirect lighting effect at the top of the dome.  

The Board of Supervisors chamber was closed when we were there, but you can look in the crack between the locked double doors and get a narrow view of a magnificent interior of carved wood walls and ceiling.

This building was completed in 1915, replacing the city hall that was destroyed in the 1906 earthquake.  

After the 1989 earthquake, there was severe damage to this building.  The city wisely decided that when restoring and strengthening that it would be restored to its original grandeur.  On the lower level, near the Grove Street entrance, there is a photo exhibit showing the massive reconstruction and restoration effort. 

The building used to house court rooms on the upper floors, but most of these have been converted to offices; however a few of them are used as hearing rooms and retain what appears to be original appearances of the old court rooms. 

If you enjoy beaux-arts architecture, you will enjoy wandering around this grand public building.  A good destination for tourists (even local ones).  It is only a short walk from the Civic Center Bary/Muni station.
author: Mike M.

description: theres a security check point line like the airport..but it goes quick - if u got nothing to hide!
author: Raffaele S.

description:
My husband and I tied the know here two years ago!  I Love him more now than the day we married.   City Hall's the way to go.  I'm a laid back kinda chick and enjoyed every moment of my wedding day thanks to City Hall!   Plus, it saved me the thousands of dollars on a big wedding day and we were able to spend the money saved on other things... 

It was cheap, fast and easy!   Nothing like my marriage which is more memorable with each passing day.
author: Christine P.

description: It's a good looking building.  How many City Halls look like this?  Whenever I around here, I'm glad we don't have some dome that looks like it fell off a nearby building (ahem, San Jose).
author: Erika C.

description: I spent a NYE party there! It was awesome! don't forget to visit!
author: Andrea M.

description: I got married here! From the neighborhood hairdresser I saw that morning to the judge who officiated at the ceremony, everyone expressed genuine joy about marriage and City Hall's history with weddings. They talked to us about participating in gay weddings a couple of years earlier. I think it gave them a special appreciation for the ritual. We are lucky to have been married in a place where there were such positive feelings about marriage. Thanks, City Hall folk, for being pro-gay marriage and for spreading the joy of that to all couples. Thanks also for your lovely building and the beautiful words our officiator spoke.
author: N J.

description: This place needs air conditioning.  The offices have A/C but the rest of the building doesn't.  If you plan on getting here and you tend to sweat, then it's not gonna be pretty.  Get married on a cold day because it tends to be muggy inside City Hall.  It is really beautiful though.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Love SF City Hall (or as they call it in Gotham City, the HAllllll of Justice!). Gorgeous architecture, amazing rooms, hallways, breathtaking every time I go there, and some lucky people get to actually work there! Go and walk around, you'll be glad you did!
author: Timothy C.

description: My friend got her wedding ceremony here. Love the architect!
author: Freya-Loki O.

description:
I love to intern here twice a week in the John Avalos office. It's a lot of fun, and they have some sound exhibition which also love because it really gives life to the building. 

I can't wait to be married here one day. =D
author: Sophia G.

description: I want to get married there but I heard it's haunted! The security seems very good though and it was very clean. I appreciated that the bathrooms were fully stocked3
author: Carrie W.

description: Wow absolutely beautiful! I had a reception here last night and it was spectacular. The interior is just as gorgeous as the exterior. Once passing the security screening there are several large, open rooms. There were tables, bars, and food stations set up throughout and we were able to explore the entire building. It seems like a great place to host a party or have your wedding.
author: Kathy A.

description:
So beautiful! The architecture and lighting made my sister's wedding a dream come true. We didn't rent out the whole place, but they opted for a 20 minute ceremony block. 

As we waited for their ceremony to start, we watched Gavin Newsom swear in a few public officials. And earlier in the day, we got our grub on in the reasonably priced, decently stocked cafe (we hadn't eaten all day!). I didn't get a chance to see how smoothly the paperwork went, but both bride and groom seemed not stressed - good sign. 

We also used Ustream to broadcast live. In a pinch, we found an electrical outlet (great!) to do an emergency computer charge, and there was enough internet service to broadcast live. 

The deputy marriage commisioner was quite sweet and made the vows very well. He got a little too into taking photos (but it was a nice gesture), and thus forgot to have the witnesses actually sign the papers -- so I need to go back tomorrow :)

GREAT place to wed! Surprisingly romantic!
author: Meera G.

description:
i was here for the first time this past Friday 12/14 for my future step brother's wedding.  i'd never been before and now i understand why folks flock to this location...talk about breathtaking!  beautiful celings and wall work, just a photographer's dream for taking pictures.  during the holidays, they had a great big xmas tree beautifully decorated where they had the ceremony performed...just gorgeous.

the only complaint is how fricking long the whole process took.  we were told the appointment was at 11:30am sharp...and yet, they got married probably an hour later, crazy!  i know they had a TON of people that day, but this is something they do daily, so there shouldn't be this big delay...i was frustrated just standing around not knowing wtf was going on, waiting and guessing what would happen next!  just weird.

regardless, beautiful place to get married!
author: Sara W.

description: Amazing building. Love it so much I work there as much as I can (i.e. as much as the City pays me to). Also, bridezilla (yes, you), it's an office not your personal wedding locale, so calm the hell down as people try to get to their office; you know the one you've conveniently located your photo shoot in front of.
author: Micah H.

description:
I got married here on New Year's Eve! It was absolutely incredible. 

Having a traditional wedding held absolutely no appeal to me, so I began researching other ideas and stumbled upon the yelp reviews for SF City Hall. 

I have to echo the sentiments of others who married here. It was amazing and surprisingly romantic. 

It's a great environment in which to say your vows to the one you love because of all the love surrounding you. I had 6 family members with me and there were a few other couples around me, all dressed up, waiting for their turn to get married. Everyone was really happy and it was great to feel the happiness of others in addition to my own.
author: Jessica R.

description: My husband and I recently got married at City Hall. It was amazing!! The lighting and architecture there are incredible! You can't ask for a more beautiful location and for the price, you'll never find one. Highly recommend this spot.
author: Melissa P.

description:
This place holds a special place in my heart.

My first marriage was held here a few years ago on that cold day in February when the Mayor Gavin Newsom allowed same-sex couples to be married.  It was great while it lasted since it was nullified a few months later by the supreme court.

My girlfriend, my best friend and I left So-Cal and drove 6 hrs to get here and waited over 8hrs before we were able to know if the marriages were going to be allowed. The city employees even stayed after closing hours to complete the marriages performed that day so hundreds of couples were able to be married.  A few weeks later, the marriages were no longer allowed to be performed and the rest was history. 

If you've been to SF but have never set foot in this place, I suggest you should.  I love the architecture and the long marble staircase that lead you to the Rotunda where I was married.  It was a crazy scene.  I had a news camera in my face and at the time I was afraid that my folks would have seen it in the news, but the camera man said that they were filming for Japan. Whew! I thought. (OK, that didn't last long because somehow my mom caught me in the news anyway. Oh well.)  If ya don't know, now you know!

The vibe and buzz around the city was just so welcoming.  It was definitely worth the wait.  It's not a typical city hall, you can totally feel the history in this place.   

It was really a life changing experience and now I know why they make those shirts "I left my heart in SF."  Definitely not a boring, average city hall.  This is definitely a landmark in SF that people should visit at least once in their life.
author: Erin V.

description:
Just a couple days ago, I said 'I Do' at City Hall. My Husband and I planned a small (6 guest) ceremony. Very simple and intimate. What a beautiful location! Even though our wedding was so simple and 'low budget', we never once felt like we were compromising on location. I may be biased, but I honestly believe that it was one of the most beautiful weddings I've ever attended (And, as a Wedding Photographer, I've been to a few!).

Our Judge/Officient was so beautifully well spoken. I am not an overly sensitive sort of lady... but listening to him speak while I stood there with my soon-to-be-husband, about to say 'I Do'.. moved me to tears. It was so so touching. All of our guests were in tears as well!

We asked the Judge if he wouldnt mind doing the Ceremony on the 4th floor.. and he agree'd. We are so happy we asked! Otherwise we would have done it on the stairs... and while the stairs are beautiful, they are also very busy and the light isn't amazing. The 4th floor is MUCH more private and the light is *perfect*. Our photographer was very happy that we opted for the 4th floor--- our photos turned out beautifully with all that natural light!

All of our guests had never been to City Hall and they were all floored at how stunningly beautiful it is. It never once felt like a low budget wedding... it was simply absolutely perfect. I wouldn't go back and change a THING.
author: Tamara B.

description:
Wheee!  i got married here  last week and it was great!  
Beautiful beautiful public, historic, i am sharing my experience with all the other lovers around the world and right here in san franicisco who decided to just do it.  vegas was such a cheezy idea looking back at the options i was considering.  
ok thats it
author: yayoi s.

description:
my sister decided to have her 'low key' nuptials at the drop dead gorgeous city hall.  the venue is gorgeous -- possibly the most beautiful public building I've ever been in.  Bernice, her officiant, was just a darling, made us all cry, and added a touch of nostalgic traditional to the day. 

3 things -- 1) they tell you to be on time for your appts, which you should be, because how else would you have all that time to wait around.  2) they also tell you a max of 6 guests, but I think that unless you bus in Party Central, no one is going to stop aunt susan and uncle ed from being around. 3) bring a camera, a camcorder, a photographer, because you'll want those pics for a lifetime.
author: Sasha R.

description:
An grand and beautiful place to have a civil marriage ceremony. Deputy Commissioner Margaret Switala performs a genuinely heartfelt ceremony. Choose the main rotunda for your public declaration of commitment.

Also a must for visitors new to the city.
author: Lotte D.

description: So pretty! Free entrance plus you'll get to see a ton of people getting married at the same time
author: Diane S.

description:
I absolutely love the atmosphere of City Hall. The place is gorgeous and is a short walk from my condo, so it was a given that my husband and I would choose to say our " I do's" here. We spoke to the event planning committee about our small gathering and was given the price of a mere $1,400 dollars for an hour (anytime between the hours of 1-5 on a choice of two different floors..4th or 2nd) including chairs (but nothing else) for our 40ish guests. 

When inquiring about our event, I was told I would be receiving an email about the services with a write-up of our contract. I waited more than a week and got nothing. After I called and asked the second time, there was no information on file for us. Right after our second conversation, though, I was emailed right away with all the required documents. 

The day of the wedding, I was greeted kindly and given a room where I could await my walk down the aisle. They even placed a mirror in the room for last minute touch-ups. 

The set-up for the service wasn't finished until around 10 minutes before the actual ceremony started. In the corner of the room, a rack of chairs were left and not taken away until all my guests had arrived. I would have liked this to have been a bit quicker. 

I wasn't told that we had to hold off starting our music until our exact hour started (even though our guests were already seated and everything was ready to go). I found this a bit silly, considering we hadn't started the actual ceremony. We had violinist there to merely entertain our guests that had arrived early. My groomsmen was told to have them stop, but I wasn't told why.. so there was a big confusion and back and forth (poor musicians). 

At the end of our hour, there was an announcement made over all of City Hall saying our wedding was over (a polite way to kick us out). Funny thing, because we had already left the area... and were taking pictures in different areas of City Hall. I found this a bit rude, but hey... you do what you have to do. 

The photo opportunities were amazing in City Hall. Every corner provides something beautiful as a backdrop. 

HERE'S THE REALLLLL KICKER:
